loans.name: Puthea

texts.en:
Mr. Puthea M., aged 40, and his wife, Mrs. Chorn Port, aged 36, live in a small village along National Road Number Three, about 20 kilometers from Phnom Penh City. They have been married since 1991 and have three daughters. Their eldest daughter is a garment factory worker. Puthea was not available for the photo, so his wife is pictured instead.

Puthea has been working in a garment factory for three months. His wife stays at home and does house work. He does not have his own transportation and spends a lot of money on traveling costs very often.

To deal with this, Puthea is applying for his first loan of $250 in order to purchase a motorbike for commuting.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike for commuting.

loans.name: Phat's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Phat N. is 48 years old. She is president of a village bank which consists of 13 people located in Ankor Phdiek village, Takeo province. This loan will be used for different purposes. 

Mrs. Phat N. is married and has five children. Two are employed in the garment factory while the other three are students in the public school. She and her husband, Mr. Phan T., are farmers who own a one hectare field to grow crops. They try to work hard with their farm but they do not earn enough income to support their family. Therefore, Mrs. Phat N. is requesting 800,000 Riel from AMK to buy rice to resell. With this loan, she hopes that she can improve the living conditions of her family.

loans.use: To buy rice for resale

loans.name: Chanthy

texts.en: Mrs. Chanthy Chor, 31, is single and lives with her elderly mother in a suburb about 17 kilometers from Phnom Penh. She has been selling bread for 3 years. She buys it from a bakery in Phnom Penh and resells it in her village. She is asking for her first loan of $500 to build a fence around her house.

loans.use: To build a fence around her house.

loans.name: Bernarda

texts.en:
Bernarda C., 55, is making sure that her family has enough provisions for their daily needs. She is married to Rodulfo C., a farmer. She makes sure that she helps her husband earn income so that their family can have a better life.  She has been managing a business selling seasonal products. Currently she is selling fruit and some vegetables.

Bernarda has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for more than a year now. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she has been able to borrow quite a few times in CCT’s Cooperative.  She is consistent in paying her dues because she used the money she borrowed to expand and improve her business.     

Now with your help, she would like to apply for a PHP 12,000 loan. This amount will be used as a source of additional capital for her expanding business to buy more products needed to sustain and replenish her current inventory.

She dreams that her business will continue to grow and that she will be able to sustain the business for as long as it will last.  She also wishes that she will have good health to fully enjoy her years with her family.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to buy more products to sustain and replenish her current inventory.

loans.name: Sreypov Heang Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Sreypov H. is from the village Ankor Phdiek, Takeo province. She is 26 years old and is a village bank president of a 16-member loan offered by AMK. The loan will be used to purchase supplies, equipment and other items to use for different purposes.

She is a farmer who owns a 2-hectare field to cultivate rice. Her husband, Mr. Tom TE., is a construction worker who earns a small income to support his family.  
For this loan, Mrs. Sreypov H. is requesting 800,000 Riel from AMK to buy timber to build a house for her family. The couple has a child who is too young to study or work.

loans.use: To buy timber

loans.name: Torn

texts.en:
Mrs. Torn E. and her husband, Mr. Korn Kim, live in a small village along National Road Number 5, about 20 kilometers from Phnom Penh. They have been married since 1969 and have five children: four sons and one daughter. Two of their sons are married and live outside the family home, one is a farmer and the other son attends school. Their daughter is a garment factory worker. Torn is not in the photo, her husband was available instead. 

Torn is a farmer; she grows rice on her farmland. Mr. Korn Kim has been a fisherman since 1979. He catches fish in the river near his house and sells the fish in his village. She is asking for a loan of $1,200 to purchase a rice threshing machine to use when harvesting season comes.

loans.use: To purchase a rice threshing machine.

loans.name: Thelma Llema Group

texts.en: Thelma L. is from the village of Locsoon, Tudela, Misamis Occidental. She is 46 years old. Thelma is the group leader of a two-member group loan offered by PMPC, a Kiva partner. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are both collectively responsible for paying back the loan of their fellow group member if she is delinquent or defaults. Thelma is married and has one school-age child. To make a living, Thelma raises pigs for sale. Thelma has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 5,000 Philippine pesos a month for these activities. In 2008, Thelma joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Thelma has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase baby livestock to raise and sell in the future. Thelma is requesting a new loan of 9,500 PHP, which will be used to purchase livestock feed and other supplies. This will be the seccnd loan taken out by Thelma from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support immediate members of her family. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase livestock feed and other supplies

loans.name: Erlinda

texts.en:
Erlinda A., 48, is making sure that her family has enough provisions for their daily needs. Married to Virgilio A., a farmer and driver, she is blessed with six children. She makes sure that she helps her husband earn so that their family can have a better life. She has been managing her own fruit store for five years now.

Erlinda has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for more than a year. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she was able to borrow five times in CCT’s Cooperative. She is consistent in paying her dues because she used the money she borrowed to expand and improve her fruit business.     

Now with your help, she would like to apply for a 11,000 Philippine pesos loan. This amount will be used as a source of added capital for her expanding business to buy more fruits to increase her product inventory.

She dreams that her business will continue to grow so that she can provide for her children’s education.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group has 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: Buying more quantities of fruits to increase her product inventory

loans.name: Mao

texts.en:
Mr. Mao E. and his wife, Mrs. Sophoin Auk (pictured together), were married in 1988 and have four children: three sons and one daughter. Two of their sons are construction workers, their daughter is a garment-factory worker and another son attends school. The family lives in a small village on National Road Number Two about 20 kilometers south of Phnom Penh City.

Mao has been driving a motorcycle taxi since 1989. His wife stays at home and does housework. He is requesting a loan of $300 to build a fence for his house.

loans.use: To build a fence around his house

loans.name: Pastor

texts.en:
Pastor P., 54, manages the family farm. He works to make sure that his family has enough for their daily needs and to improve their standard of living. Married to Rodilyn P., they are blessed with three children. 

Pastor has been a regular member of the Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for more than a year now. He regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings and pays his weekly dues consistently. Because of his good repayment performance with his previous loans, he was able to borrow quite a few times in CCT’s Cooperative. He uses the money he borrows to expand and improve the farm.

Now with your help, he would like to apply for a Php 13,000 loan which will be used as a source of added capital to buy equipment and raw materials needed for the farm to continue to grow and fulfill Pastor's dream of a good and comfortable life with his family.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: buying equipment and raw materials needed for the farm to continue its production.

loans.name: Luzma Capundag Group

texts.en:
Luzma C., 40, is from the village of Senor, Sinacaban, Misamis Occidental in the Philippines. She is the group leader of a three-member group loan offered by PMPC. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Luzma is married and has five school-aged children. To make a living, Luzma owns and operates a general store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling both food and daily use products in the local community. Luzma has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 1500 PHP a month.

In 2006, Luzma joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Luzma has successfully repaid a previous loan of 4000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional inventory and working capital. Luzma is requesting a new loan of 10000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the 6th loan taken out by Luzma from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Kunthea's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. N. Kunthea is from Ta Su village, Takeo province. She is 38 years old and serves as the leader for this 5-member group loan offered by AMK. 
A farmer who owns a plot of land to grow crops, she also breeds pigs. In order to support her pig breeding, she decided to ask for a loan to buy pig food. Her husband, Mr. Savoeun Soeun works in a tobacco company which brings in a small salary to contribute to their living situation.

loans.use: To buy pig food

loans.name: Snooky

texts.en:
Snooky T., 38, is making sure that her family has adequate provision for their daily needs. She is married to Alfredo T. and they are blessed with a child. She makes sure that she helps her husband earn so that their family can have a better life. She has been managing her own variety store and food stall for quite some time now.

Snooky has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation (CCT) for more than a year now. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings* and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she was able to borrow seven times in CCT’s cooperative. She is consistent in paying her dues because she used the money she borrowed to expand and improve her variety store and food stall.

Now, with your help, Snooky would like to obtain a PHP 17,000 loan. This amount will be used as a source of added capital for her expanding business by buying raw ingredients needed to cook her recipes and additional groceries to replenish stocks in her variety store.

Snooky dreams that her business will continue to grow so that she can provide for her child’s education. She also wants to have a bigger stall where she can sell more of her products.


* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of fifteen to thirty community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay micro-finance loans.

loans.use: To buy additional groceries for her store and added ingredients

loans.name: Thoek

texts.en:
Mrs. Thoek K. is 35 years old and she lives in Moeang Prachen village, Takeo province. She is a farmer who owns 1.5 hectares (3.75 acres) of land which she cultivates. Her husband; Mr. Lorn Ly, is a fisherman and he is shown on the right in the photo.

In order to support her growing crops, Thoek K. decided to ask for a loan to dig a well. The rest of the loan she would use to buy baby fish to raise.

Thoek K. is the mother of five children, four of whom are students in the local public school and also help their parents as part of their daily chores, while the youngest one is too young to study or work.

loans.use: To dig a well and to buy baby fish

loans.name: Annaliza

texts.en:
Annaliza M., 31, is making sure that her family has adequate provision for their daily needs. She is married to Reymar M., a shoe maker and electronics repairman, and they are blessed with three children. She makes sure that she helps her husband earn so that their family can have a better life.  She has been managing her own variety store for four years.

Annaliza has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation (CCT) for more than a year now. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings* and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she was able to borrow quite a few times from CCT’s cooperative.  She is consistent in paying her dues because she used the money she borrowed to expand and improve her variety store.     

Now, with your help, Annaliza would like to obtain a PHP 12,000 loan. This amount will be used as a source of added capital for her expanding business by buying more groceries to be incorporated into her current product inventory.

Annaliza dreams that her business will continue to grow so that her children will be able to have a good education and their whole family will be able to have good health. She also prays that the Lord will always guide her and her family in everything they do.


* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of fifteen to thirty community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay micro-finance loans.

loans.use: To buy more groceries for her store

loans.name: Eloisa

texts.en:
Eloisa B., 48, is making sure that her family has adequate provision for their daily needs. She is married to Jaime B., a businessman, and they are blessed with five children. She makes sure that she helps her husband earn so that their family can have a better life. She has been managing her own printing press for five years.

Eloisa has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation (CCT) for more than a year now. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings* and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she was able to borrow quite a few times from CCT’s cooperative. She is consistent in paying her dues because she used the money she borrowed to expand and improve her printing press business.

Now, with your help, Eloisa would like to obtain a PHP 9,000 loan. This amount will be used as a source of added capital for her expanding business by buying raw supplies needed to make the printing press continuous in its operations.

Eloisa dreams that her children finish their education and have good, stable jobs in the future.


* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of fifteen to thirty community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay micro-finance loans.

loans.use: To buy raw supplies for her printing press business

loans.name: Brok's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Brok N. is 60 years old and single. She is one member of a three-member village loan group in Ta Su Village, Takeo Province. 

Mrs. Brok N. sells groceries and vegetables in the local market. Since her business is going well, she wants to expand it. Thus, she decided to ask for a loan from AMK to purchase more groceries and vegetable to expand her business. With this loan, she hopes to increase her income and improve her living conditions.

loans.use: To purchase more groceries and vegetable

loans.name: Mary Jane

texts.en:
Mary Jane E., age 41, is making sure that her family has enough provisions for their daily needs. She is married to Jose E., a driver, and they are blessed with three children. She makes sure that she helps her husband earn so that their family can have a better life.  She has been buying and selling cosmetics and branded apparels for two years now.

Mary Jane has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for more than a year now. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she was able to borrow quite a few times in CCT’s Cooperative.  She is consistent in paying her dues because she used the money she borrowed to expand and improve her business.     

Now with your help, she would like to apply for a PHP 12,000 loan. This amount will be used as a source of added capital to her expanding business by buying additional cosmetic products and branded apparels that she can sell.

She dreams that her business will continue to grow so that she can provide for her children’s education. She also prays that the whole family will have a closer relationship with each other and with the Heavenly Father.
 

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: buying additional cosmetics and branded apparels that she can sell

loans.name: Nilda

texts.en: To make a living, Nilda A. operates a family member's retail store selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap and toothpaste in her community. She is 46 years old, married and has three school-age children. They are from the village of Estefania, Amulung, Cagayan. Nilda has been in her business for over three years and earns approximately 5,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month. In 2006, Nilda joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living conditions and enable her to engage in business activities. Nilda has successfully repaid a previous loan from ASKI. Nilda is requesting a new loan of 25,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be her seventh loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue to financially support immediate members of her family. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the central and northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs. Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Rio Bulay Group

texts.en:
Rio B. is from the village of Locsoon in Tudela, Misamis Occidental. She is 29 years old. Rio is the leader of a 2-member loan group sponsored by PMPC. Although each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for repaying the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Rio is married and has one young child. To make a living, Rio owns and operates a general store where she sells food and daily-use products in the local community. Rio has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 3000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2009, Rio joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Rio has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Rio is requesting a new loan of 7000 PHP to purchase new items to expand her inventory. This will be Rio second loan from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Hem

texts.en:
Hem C., age 44, is married and resides with his wife in Phnom Penh City, Cambodia. He has three children. Two of his children study at a local primary school. He grows vegetable, earning approximately $3.00 in revenue per day. He has been in this business since 2002. 

His wife helps him on their plot of farmland every day. She is able to earn an income of USD $3.00 per day to help cover the family expenses. Their standard of living has improved since they have had these businesses, so they want a loan to expand their businesses. 

C. is requesting a loan of $1000 USD to purchase a motorbike to transport his vegetables to the market to sell and buy more vegetable seeds. This is his first loan from CREDIT, a Kiva field partner.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike for his vegetable business

loans.name: Concepcion

texts.en:
Concepcion B., age 37, is making sure that her family has enough provisions for their daily needs. She is married to Aladino B. Jr., an electrician, and they are blessed with three children. She makes sure that she helps her husband earn so that their family can have a better life.  She manages her own ukay-ukay (second-hand imported clothing) business.

Concepcion has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for more than a year now. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she was able to borrow five times in CCT’s Cooperative.  She is consistent in paying her dues because she used the money she borrowed to expand and improve her ukay-ukay business.     

Now with your help, she would like to apply for a PHP 12,000 loan. This amount will be used as a source of added capital for her expanding business. She will use her loan to buy more clothing to sell.

She dreams about having a modest-sized place to sell her products. This will improve her income so she can provide for her children’s education.


* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To buy more clothes to sell

loans.name: Welma

texts.en:
Welma D. is 44 years old. She ensures that her family has enough provisions to meet their daily needs by selling firewood and charcoal, which she has been doing for quite some time now. Welma is married to Gualberto D., who is a driver, and they are blessed with six children. She helps her husband provide for their family so that they can have a better life.

Welma has been a regular member of the Center for Community Transformation (CCT)* for more than a year now. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she has been able to borrow six times from CCT’s Cooperative. She is consistent in paying her dues because she uses the money she borrows to expand and improve her natural fuel business.

Now with your help, she would like to apply for a loan of 10,000 PHP. This amount will be used to buy raw materials and supplies needed to continue the production of her fuel and expand her business.

Welma dreams that her business will continue to grow so that she can provide a good and stable education for her children.

* All CCT community partners and clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To buy raw materials and supplies needed to continue the production of fuel.

loans.name: Ky

texts.en: Ky K. is 35 years old and is married. He resides with his wife in Phnom Penh City, Cambodia. He has a five-year-old child. He is employed at a cigarette company in the city, earning approximately 4 USD in revenue per day. He has been with this company since 2006. His wife sells vegetables and fruits at a local market, and she is able to earn a gross income of 50 USD per day to help cover the family expenses. Their standard of living has improved since they started these businesses. They would now like a loan in order to expand their businesses. K. is requesting a loan of 300 USD to purchase more vegetables and fruits for his wife to sell at the market. This is his first loan from CREDIT and partnered with Kiva.

loans.use: Buy more fruits and vegetables to sell.

loans.name: Lorena

texts.en:
Lorena A., 33, is making sure that her family has enough provisions for their daily needs. She is married to Joey A. and they are blessed with a child. She makes sure that she helps her husband earn so that their family can have a better life. She has been managing her own variety store for quite some time now.

Lorena has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for more than a year now. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she was able to borrow quite a few times in CCT’s Cooperative.  She is consistent in paying her dues because she used the money she borrowed to expand and improve her variety store.     

Now with your help, she would like to apply for a PHP 10,000 loan. This amount will be used as a source of added capital for her expanding business. She will use the loan funds to buy groceries to replenish the inventory of her variety store.

She dreams that her business will continue to grow so that she can provide for her child’s education.


* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To buy groceries to sell

loans.name: Agapita

texts.en:
Agapita G., 54, makes rugs and recycles curtains. She works to ensure that her family has enough income for their daily needs. She is married to Romeo G., a construction worker, and they are blessed with five children. She helps her husband earn so that their family can have a better life.  

Agapita has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for more than a year now. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she was able to borrow seven times in CCT’s Cooperative.  She is consistent in paying her dues because she used the money she borrowed to expand and improve her businesses.     

Now with your help, she would like to apply for a PHP 10,000 loan. This amount will be used as a source of added capital for her expanding business. She will use the loan funds to buying equipment so she can expand her rug and curtain business.

She dreams that her business will continue to grow because she wants a simple life for herself, and she wants her children to have the best life she can possibly give them.


* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To buy equipment

loans.name: Em

texts.en:
Em Y., age 39, is married and lives with his wife in Phnom Penh, Cambodia. He has three school-aged children. He transports passengers on his motorbike in the city, earning approximately $10.00 in revenue per day. He has been in this business since 2000. His wife is employed in a local soymilk factory and she is able to earn an income of $4.00 per day to help cover the family expenses. 

Their standard of living has improved since they started these businesses, so they want a loan to expand their businesses. Y. is requesting a loan of 1000 USD to repair his old motorbike and attach a passenger compartment to it. He wants to become a tuk-tuk driver because he thinks that this business will allow him to earn more income. This is his first loan from CREDIT, a Kiva field partner.

loans.use: To repair his motorbike and attach a passenger compartment

loans.name: Dante

texts.en: Dante C.'s main source of income comes from planting and harvesting rice for sale. He is 34 years old, married and has two young children. They are from the village of Baculud, Iguig, Cagayan. Dante has been in his business for over 20 years and earns approximately 8,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month. In 2007, Dante joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living conditions and enable him to engage in business activities. Dante has successfully repaid a previous loan of 23,000 PHP from ASKI which was used to purchase fertilizers and other needed materials for his rice field. Dante is requesting a new loan of 28,000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. This will be his sixth loan from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue to make improvements to his house. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the central and northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs. Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers such as manure

loans.name: Chanthy's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Chanthy P. is 37 years old, She is a married woman who lives in Ta Su Village in Takeo Province. She earns a living by farming vegetables. The couple has three children who attend the local school.

Her husband, Mr. Vann Sae, is motorbike taxi driver who earns a small income to support his family. Mrs. Chanthy P. has owns a water machine to irrigate her farm, but her water machine is broken. Thus, she is applying for a loan of 600,000 Riel from AMK to buy a new water machine for her farm. She hopes to earn additional revenue so she can improve her family's living conditions.

loans.name: Leila Liga Group

texts.en:
Leila L. is from the village of Sta.Cruz in Sinacaban, Misamis Occidental. She is 33 years old. Leila is the leader of a 3-member loan group sponsored by PMPC. Although each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for repaying the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Leila is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Leila owns and operates a general store where she sells food and daily-use products in the local community. Leila has been engaged in her business for over 7 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2008, Leila joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Leila has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Leila is requesting a new loan of 9000 PHP to purchase additional inventory and use as working capital. This will be Leila's second loan from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.name: Amelita

texts.en:
Amelita T., 53, is making sure that her family has enough provisions for their daily needs. She is married to Henry T., a school owner. She makes sure that she helps her husband earn so that their family can have a better life. She has been managing her own mineral-water station and preschool for quite some time now.

Amelita has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for more than a year. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she was able to borrow 10 times in CCT’s Cooperative. She is consistent in paying her dues because she used the money she borrowed to expand and improve her businesses.     

Now with your help, she would like to apply for a 10,000 Philippine pesos loan. This amount will be used as a source of added capital to her expanding business by buying mineral water that she will supply to her customers.

She dreams that her business will continue to grow so that she can attract more students and have enough finances to renovate the school into a child’s dream of a schoolroom.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: Buying mineral water that she will supply to her customers

Umedchon intends to plant wheat and gather a good harvest for sale. This way he will make a big profit and expand his business.

loans.name: Jacob

texts.en:
Jacob is 45 years old and married. He has six children between 6 and 16 years of age, all of whom attend school. He operates a mixed farm in Western Kenya, near the town of Kitale, where he's been farming for five years. Along with his horticulture activities, Jacob frequently performs carpentry and masonry work in his community for additional income. He says that the main challenge he faces right now is that he is so busy in carpentry work that he has trouble dedicating enough time to all of his other business operations.

Jacob recently repaid a Kes. 30,000 loan from Juhudi Kilimo and has now requested this loan for Kes. 71,600 to purchase and insure a dairy cow. He will also use part of the loan to purchase farm supplies, such as a donkey cart, and material for a new dairy shed. He says that this loan will benefit his family in many ways, especially with the availability of additional milk. He also plans to use the donkey cart in a small scale transport business, charging other farmers to carry their goods to markets. In the future, Jacob wants to open a wholesale shop and would, one day, like to acquire a tractor for plowing services.

loans.use: To purchase a dairy cow and farm supplies

loans.name: Shybar Group

texts.en: Pashtana is this group’s leader. She is a business lady who is 27 years old. She is married with three children all going to school. She is a tailor and this has been her business for over three years. Due to insufficient capital, she is using the loan to add to her capital and purchase a new sewing machine and more clothes. She is a promising business lady whose dream is to improve on her family’s welfare. The second member is Najeeba. She has the business of bead working. She wants to take a loan and purchase different colors beads, strings and clothes. And through her business profits, she supports her family. The third member is Malalay. She has the business of embroidery. She wants to take a loan and purchase clothes and strings and through it, complete her family needs. The fourth member is Noorzia. She has the business of quilt making. She wants to purchase cotton cloth and string with this loan to supports her husband and children. The last member is Rayhana. She is a tailor. Due to her family economic problems, she wants to take a loan and purchase a new sewing machine and cloth. Through her business profits, she solves her family's economic problems. Therefore, they all have requested a group loan of 50,000 afghani. They would like to thanks both Kiva and AFS lenders through their effective process in Afghanistan.
