Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase new items.

loans.name: Luisa Celsia

texts.pt:
Luísa Celsia M. nasceu na cidade da Matola, Província de Maputo, sul de Moçambique tem 29 anos de idade, casada e mãe de 1 filho de 4 anos de idade, não vai a escola. Fez 11ª classe não continuou devido a falta de condições financeiras por parte dos pais. Vive na casa de familiares com sua irmã e não sustenta mais ninguém.
Saiu da Matola para Boane com os seus pais ainda jovem, actualmente continua vivendo em Boane. Trabalha como professora a 4 anos, é do quadro do Ministério da Educação, foi formada pelo Centro de formação de Professores. Faz cerca de 6 horas por dia e tem um salário de 6.350.00mt por mês, que aplica nas despesas de casa e ainda poupa algum na sua conta bancária mensalmente.
Nunca teve empréstimos em outros bancos. Conheceu a Hluvuku através de seus colegas que também são clientes desta instituição. Este é o seu 3º empréstimo no valor de 20.000.00mt com o qual pretende comprar material de construção (chapas de zinco, cimento, portas e janelas) para dar continuidade com a sua obra. Os empréstimos anteriores foram de 10.000.00mt e 20.000.00mt todos para a mesma actividade.
No futuro gostaria de solicitar mais empréstimos para concluir a sua obra e oferecer melhor comodidade a sua família.
texts.en:
Luisa Celsia M. was born in the city of Matola, in the province of Maputo in the south of Mozambique. She is 29 years old, is married, and has a four year old son who is not yet yet in school. She studied through 11th grade but didn't continue because of her parents' lack of financial resources. She lives along with her sister in the house of other relatives, and is not helping to support anyone else. . She left Matola for Boane with her parents when she was young, and Boane is where she still lives. She's been working as a teacher for 4 years, as part of the Ministry of Education, and she studied in the Centro de Formação de Professores [Teacher Education Center]. She works around 6 hours a day and has a salary of 6.350.00mt per month, which she puts towards household expenses, also saving some each month in her bank account. Luisa Celsia has never taken out a loan with another bank. She found out about Hluvuku through some colleagues who are also customers of the institution. This is her third loan, in the amount of 20.000.00mt. She plans to use this money to buy construction materials (zinc plates, cement, doors and windows) to continue with her project. The earlier loans were for 10.000.00mt and 20.000.00mt, both for the same undertaking. In the future she would like to apply for more loans to finish the project and offer her family a more comfortable life.

Translated from Portuguese by Catherine Fountain, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of construction materials

loans.name: Shirley

texts.en:
Shirley T. is from the village of Banquero. She is 43 years old. Shirley is married and has 3 adult children. Shirley owns & operates a general store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Shirley has been engaged in her business for over 22 years and earns approximately 3,500 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month (about $76 US) for these activities.

In 2010, Shirley joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business. Shirley is requesting her first loan, for 7000 PHP, which will be used to purchase new items to expand her product offerings.  She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand the business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To expand store inventory

loans.name: Bernardo

texts.pt:
Bernardo A. nasceu na Província de Inhambane, sul de Moçambique tem 39 anos de idade, casado e pai de 2 filhos de 5 e 1 anos de idade, não vão a escola. Fez 10ª classe não continuou devido a falta de condições financeiras por parte dos pais. Vive na casa própria com a sua família e não sustenta mais ninguém.
Saiu de Inhambane para Maputo quando tinha 7 anos de idade com os seus pais, mais tarde muda se para o Distrito de Boane bairro da Massaca com a sua família. Tem um negócio próprio, de criação e venda de frangos de corte é dono dos aviários a mais de 2 anos e não possui nenhum empregado. Compra os pintos por 18.00mt e vende a 90.00mt o frango, neste negócio consegue um rendimento de cerca de 5.000.00mt por mês, que aplica nas despesas de casa e ainda poupa algum na sua conta bancária mensalmente.
Nunca teve empréstimos em outros bancos. Conheceu a Hluvuku através de seus amigos que também são clientes desta instituição. Este é o seu 2º empréstimo no valor de 18.000.00mt com o qual pretende comprar produtos (pintos, ração, vacinas e outros) para dar continuidade com a sua actividade comercial. O empréstimo anterior foi de 15.000.00mt para a mesma actividade.
Compromete se a pagar devidamente este empréstimo para poder aceder a outros. No futuro gostaria de solicitar mais empréstimos para construir mais aviários e desenvolver cada vez mais o seu negócio.
texts.en:
Bernardo A. was born in the province of Inhambane, in the south of Mozambique. He is 39 years old, married, and has two children who are 1 and 5 years old. Neither is currently in school. He studied through the 10th grade but didn't continue because of his parents' lack of financial resources. He lives in his own home with his family and is not helping to support anyone else. Bernardo left Inhambane for Maputo with his parents when he was 7 years old. Later he moved to the Massaca neighborhood in the district of Boane with his family. He has his own business, raising and selling broiler chickens. He has owned two chicken coops for the past 2 years and does not employ any outside help. He buys the baby chicks for 18.00mt and sells the grown chickens for 90.00mt. This business gives him a monthly income of almost 5.000.00mt, which he uses to pay household expenses. He is also able to save some money in his bank account each month. He has never had loans with other banks. He found out about Hluvuku [the Kiva field partner] through friends of his who are also customers of the institution. This is his 2nd loan, in the amount of 18.000.00mt. He plans to use this money to buy products (baby chicks, feed, vaccines and other items) to continue with his business venture. His previous loan was for 15.000.00mt and was used for the same purpose. Bernardo promises to repay the loan as stated, so that he can get other loans in the future. He would like to borrow more money to build more chicken coops and continue developing his business.

Translated from Portuguese by Catherine Fountain, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of chicken feed

loans.name: Rebbeca

texts.en: Local gin in Nigeria has various nicknames like "sapele water", "paraga", "push me i push u". These nicknames for the local gin have made it popular in Nigeria. To make a living in Sapele, Rebbeca sells local gin at retail prices to her customers. She loves this business because of the one-on-one interacation that she has with her customers. She hopes for a loan amount of 80,000 Nigerian naira to purchase more local gin to sell. She is 39 years old and married with 8 children. Her husband is a businessman and he also supports his homes. She hopes to grow her business. She duly thanks all Kiva lenders in anticipation for the loan.

loans.use: To purchase more local gin to sell

loans.name: Eni Ilda

texts.pt:
Eni Ilda B. nasceu na cidade de Maputo, sul de moçambique tem 40 anos de idade, solteira e mãe de 3 filhos de 20, 17, e 7 anos de idade, todos vão a escola. Fez somente 8ª classe não continuou devido a falta de condições financeiras. Vive na casa própria com os seus e não sustenta mais ninguém para alem dos filhos.
Saiu do bairro de aeroporto na cidade Maputo para o Distrito de Boane no ano de 2007 com os seus folhos. Ė Negociante e dona do seu próprio negocio a mais de 15 anos, trabalha das 08:00horas as 18:00horas e não possui nenhum empregado. Aprendeu esta actividade com a sua prima que também desenvolve o mesmo negócio, vende mais farinha, leite em pó, iogurtes e café. Consegue um rendimento de cerca de 5.000.00mt por mês, que aplica nas despesas de casa e ainda poupa algum na sua conta bancária mensalmente.
Já teve empréstimos na Associação de micro finanças TCHUMA, onde mais tarde decidiu não continuar devido a varias razoes. Conheceu a Hluvuku através da sua prima que também é cliente desta instituição. Este é o seu 2º empréstimo no valor de 15.000.00mt com o qual pretende comprar produtos (farinha, arroz, leite em pó, café e outros) para aumentar a quantidade da sua mercadoria. O empréstimo anterior foi de 7.000.00mt para a mesma actividade.
 Compromete se a pagar devidamente este empréstimo para poder aceder a outros. No futuro gostaria de solicitar mais empréstimos para ampliar o seu estabelecimento comercial e satisfazer a demanda da sua clientela.
texts.en:
Eni Ilda B. was born in the city of Maputo, in southern Mozambique. She is 40 years old and is a single mother of three children, ages 20, 17, and 7. All three go to school. She only finished eighth grade; she didn't continue because of financial problems. She lives in her own house with her family and has no dependents besides her children. She left the airport district in Maputo city to go to Boane District in 2007 with her children. She has had her own business for more than 15 years. She works from 8:00 am to 6:00 pm and has no employees. She learned this job with her cousin who also runs the same type of business. She sells flour, powdered milk, yogurt and coffee. She makes around 5,000 MZN per month, which she uses for household expenses and even manages to put some money in her bank account every month. She has taken out loans before with the TCHUMA micro-finance association, but she decided not to continue with them for various reasons. She heard about Hluvuku through her cousin, who is also a client of this institution. This is her second loan. She asks for 15,000 MZN, which she will use to buy products (flour, rice, powdered milk, coffee and other items) to increase her inventory. The first loan was for 7,000 MZN for the same purpose. She promises to pay off this loan on time so she will be able to get other loans. In the future, she would like to take out more loans in order to expand her shop and meet her customers' demands.

Translated from Portuguese by Danielle Maxson, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase and sale of groceries

loans.name: Euloge

texts.fr: Né le 11 mars 1965 à Porto-Novo, capitale administrative du BENIN, K. Euloge vit depuis bientôt 10 ans à Abokicodji, un quartier de Cotonou, capitale économique du BENIN. Marié à HODONOU Irène, une ménagère et couturière,  Euloge est père de 2 enfants qui sont tous scolarisés. La famille vit ensemble et le couple assure les charges familiales. Euloge a fréquenté l’école jusqu’à l’université. Mais depuis une quinzaine d’année, Euloge mène comme activité la vente de fournitures de bureau  dans sa boutique size à Abokicodji. C’est à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin que Euloge fait ses achats. C’est un ancien client de ALIDé, ayant déjà obtenu cinq crédits auprès de l’institution. Ces cinq crédits ont été tous bien remboursés. La clientèle de Euloge s’accroît au jour le jour et il n’arrive plus à satisfaire tous ses clients. C’est pour renforcer son activité et satisfaire les nombreuses demandes de sa clientèle, que Euloge sollicite un sixième prêt auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
Euloge K. was born on March 11, 1965 in Porto-Novo, the administrative capital of Benin. For almost 10 years he has been living in Abokicodji, a neighborhood of Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. He is married to Irene Hodonou, a homemaker and seamstress. Euloge is the father of two children all attending school. The family lives together and the couple provides for the family’s expenses. Euloge attended school up to University level. However, for the last 15 years he has been selling office supplies in his store located in Abokicodji. Euloge gets his goods at Dantokpa, international market of Benin. He is a previous ALIDé client; he has already obtained five loans from the institution. These five loans have all been fully reimbursed. Euloge’ s clientele expands more and more each day and he can no longer meet the needs of all his customers. In order to bolster his activity and to satisfy the many demands of his customers, Euloge is requesting a sixth loan from ALIDé.

Translated from French by Véronique Fourment, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of office supplies.

loans.name: Valentina Da Conceicao

texts.pt:
Valentina Da Conceição D. M. nasceu na cidaD. D. Maputo, sul D. moçambique tem 44 anos D. idaD., separada e mãe D. 3 filhos D. 21, 17, e 14 anos D. idaD., todos vão a escola. Fez somente 8ª classe não continuou devido a gravidez precoce e não lhe foi permitida o regresso a escola pelo marido depois do parto. Vive na casa própria com a sua sobrinha porque os filhos ficaram com o pai após a separação, sustenta sua mãe que não vive com ela enviando dinheiro e bens alimentícios.
Saiu da cidaD. da Matola para Boane a 7 anos depois da separação, continua vivendo neste distrito com a sua sobrinha. Tem um negócio próprio a mais D. 7 anos, faz cerca D. 12 horas D. trabalho por dia, venD. mais cerveja e refrescos e não possui nenhum empregado. Aprendeu esta actividaD. com as suas amigas que viviam no mesmo bairro da cidaD. da Matola. Consegue um rendimento D. cerca D. 5.000.00mt por mês, que aplica nas despesas D. casa e ainda poupa algum em casa para responder a eventual despesas que possam surgir.
Nunca teve empréstimos em outros bancos, conheceu a Hluvuku através da sua amiga que também é cliente desta instituição. Este é o seu 4º empréstimo no valor D. 15.000.00mt com o qual pretenD. comprar produtos (refrescos, cerveja, vinho e outros) para aumentar a quantidaD. da sua mercadoria. Os empréstimos anteriores foram D. 9.000.00mt, 14.000.00mt e 10.000.00mt todos para a mesma actividaD..
 No futuro gostaria D. solicitar mais empréstimos para construir um estabelecimento comercial fixo e D. material convencional para satisfazer a demanda da sua clientela.
texts.en:
Valentina Da Conceição D. M. was born in the city of Maputo, in southern Mozambique. She is 44 years old, is separated from her husband and is the mother of 3 children aged 21, 17, and 14. They all attend school. Valentina only completed eighth graD.; she did not continue because of an early pregnancy. Her husband did not allow her to return to school after the baby's birth. She lives in her own house with her niece because her children stayed with their father after their separation. She supports her mother, who does not live with her, by sending her money and food. She left the city of Matola to go to Boane seven years after the separation. She is still living in this district with her niece. She has had her own business for more than seven years. She works about 12 hours per day selling beer and soft drinks, and she has no employees. Valentina learned this job with some friends who lived in her neighborhood in Matola. She makes about 5,000 MZN per month, which she uses for household expenses while saving some money at home for unexpected expenses. Valentina has never taken out loans from other banks. She learned about Hluvuku through a friend who is also a client here. This is Valentina's fourth loan. She is asking for 15,000 MZN, which she will use to buy products (soft drinks, beer, wine and other products) to increase her inventory. The other loans were for 9,000 MZN, 1,000 MZN, and 10,000 MZN. The other loans were used for the same purpose. In the future, she would like to ask for more loans in order to build a shop.

Translated from Portuguese by Danielle Maxson, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase and sale of beverages

loans.name: Melia's Group

texts.en:
Melia D. is from the village of Bacnor East. She is 46 years old. Melia is the group leader of a 7-member group loan offered by ASKI/Kiva. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Melia D. group.

Melia is married and has 4 school-aged children. She owns and operates a general store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Melia has been involved in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2009, Melia joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Melia has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from ASKI, which was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Melia is requesting a second loan of 15000 PHP which will be used to purchase new items to expand product offering. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase new items to expand product offering

loans.name: Teresita

texts.en:
Teresita B. is one of the newest members in her ASHI center. Her business is not yet as big as the others, however she together with her family spends wisely the small profit they get out of it for their basic needs. Certainly, Teresita wants her hog fattening business to grow more while her children are still young (they are two and four years old). 

Hog/pig fattening is a kind of business wherein after four months of fattening, the hog/pig can be sold alive or slaughtered. The more hogs one can sell, the more the profit, which is why Teresita is requesting a much larger loan to buy more piglets for fattening. 

Her business proceeds will be saved while her husband’s income from a tricycle taxi (a motorcycle and sidecar, the Filipino version of a rickshaw), will be spent for their daily expenses. Teresita wants to save some amount of money for their education someday and to build a house they can call their own.

loans.use: For pigs and feed

loans.name: Marta Armando

texts.pt:
Marta Amando M. nasceu no Bairro da Machava, cidade de Maputo, Província do mesmo nome, tem 25 anos de idade, casada e mãe de3 filhos de 7, 4 e 1 anos de idade, o mais velho é que vai a escola. Fez somente4ą classe não continuou devido a falta de condições financeiras. Vive na casa própria com familiares não sustenta mais ninguém para alem da sua família. 
Saiu de Macahava para Boane com os pais ainda jovem, porque estes tinham machambas agrícolas. Depois do casamento continuou a residir em Boane, onde desenvolve o seu negócio. Trabalha das 7:00h as 18:00h todos os dias, vende mais panelas que adquire por 5.000.00mt e vende por 8.500.00mt, não possui nenhum empregado. Deste negócio consegue um rendimento de cerca de 3.500.00mt por mês, que aplica nas despesas de casa e ainda poupa algum na sua conta bancária.
Nunca teve empréstimos em outros bancos, conheceu a Hluvuku através de amigos que também são clientes desta instituição. Este é o seu 4º empréstimo no valor de 11.000.00mt com o qual pretende comprar material (chapas de zinco, pedra, cimento, areia e outros) para dar continuidade com a sua obra. Os empréstimos anteriores foram de 3.100.00mt, 8.000.00mt e 10.000.00mt todos para a mesma actividade.
Compromete se a pagar devidamente este empréstimo para poder aceder a outros. No futuro gostaria de solicitar mais empréstimos para concluir a sua residência adquirir um meio de transporte.
texts.en:
Marta Amando M. was born in the Machava district, city of Maputo, Maputo province. She is 25 years old, is married and has three children aged 7, 4, and 1. The eldest attends school. Marta only finished fourth grade; she couldn't continue for financial reasons. She lives in her own house with relatives and has no dependents other than her family. When Marta was young, she left Machava to move to Boane with her parents because they had machambas (small family farms). After her marriage she continued living in Boane, where she started her business. She works from 7:00 am until 6:00 pm everyday selling pots that she buys for 5,000 MZN and sells for 8,500 MZN. She has no employees. From this business she earns about 3,500 MZN per month, which she uses for household expenses and even manages to put something in the bank. Marta has never taken out loans from other banks. She learned about Hluvuku through friends who are also clients here. This is her fourth loan. She is asking for 11,000 MZN, with which she wants to buy materials (zinc sheets, stone, cement, sand and other materials) to continue building her house. Her previous loans were for 3,100 MZN, 8,000 MZN and 10,000 MZN, all for the same purpose. She promises to pay off this loan on time so she can receive more loans. In the future, she would like to ask for more loans so she can finish her house and buy some type of transportation.

Translated from Portuguese by Danielle Maxson, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of construction materials

loans.name: Dora

texts.en: Dora sells tubers of yams, plantain, and cocoa yam to earn a living. Yams in Nigeria can be eaten by boiling, frying, pounding and roasting. They are a staple food in Nigeria and Nigerians love them.  Dora hopes for a loan amount of 100,000 Nigerian naira to purchase more tubers of yams to sell. She is 52 years old and married with 7 children. Her husband is a businessman and he also supports the home. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more tubers of yam to sell.

loans.name: Rosa

texts.en:
In a small village near the sea, in the municipality of San Jose in Antique province, Rosa R. and her husband raised her two children. They had very little money then, but were determined to graduate their two children from college and to get out from under the burden of poverty.  They decided to take out a loan from ASHI and start a business to have some source of income. 

After Rosa became a member of ASHI in 1996, her business went quite well and she made her dream for her children come true. Both have graduated from college and have a family of their own now. Despite that, Rosa still wants to be financially independent from her children. 

With her husband, she wants to attend to her own life by growing her tailoring and fish vending business. Therefore, she is requesting a loan to support her plan; now that her children have their own family life, she wants to be financially secure and renovate her house to be a better dwelling in preparation for her and her husband’s old age. She also wants to help her children send their children to school.

loans.use: To purchase fish for selling and some materials for tailoring.

loans.name: Lilibeth

texts.en:
Lilibeth B. is from the town of Alicia, Isabela. She is 41 years old. Lilibeth is married and has four adult-aged children. To make a living, Lilibeth owns and operates a general store, selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap and toothpaste in the local community. Lilibeth has been engaged in her business for over ten years and earns approximately $115 a month from this activity.

In 2007, Lilibeth joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation by engaging in business activities. Lilibeth is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be her 4th loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful micro-finance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Julienne

texts.fr: A. Julienne est née le 12 Avril 1957 et est mariée à JOHNSON Prosper, un comptable retraité. Le couple a trois enfants, tous scolarisés, dont un reste encore à leur charge. Il y a 5 ans environs que Julienne s’est installée au quartier Gbéto à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin, où elle vit avec sa famille. Julienne assure ensemble avec son mari les charges de la famille. N’ayant fréquenté que le cours primaire, Julienne a commencé depuis 10 ans la vente de divers produits (produits cosmétiques, lait, mayonnaise, huile d'arachide, conserve de sardine, liqueurs, couscous etc.), une activité qui lui procure des revenus lui permettant de subvenir à ses besoins. Julienne vend également des liqueurs, de façon secondaire. C’est à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin que Julienne s’approvisionne. Mais Julienne vend ses produits dans sa boutique à Cotonou. Julienne est une ancienne cliente de ALIDé qui rembourse bien ses crédits. Malgré la passion qu’elle a pour son activité, Julienne ne dispose pas suffisamment de moyens financiers pouvant lui permettre de faire face à la nombreuse demande de sa clientèle. C’est au vue de cela que Julienne sollicite un autre crédit auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
A. Julienne est née le 12 Avril 1957 et est mariée à JOHNSON Prosper, un comptable retraité. Le couple a trois enfants, tous scolarisés, dont un reste encore à leur charge. Il y a 5 ans environs que Julienne s’est installée au quartier Gbéto à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin, où elle vit avec sa famille. Julienne assure ensemble avec son mari les charges de la famille. N’ayant fréquenté que le cours primaire, Julienne a commencé depuis 10 ans la vente de divers produits (produits cosmétiques, lait, mayonnaise, huile d'arachide, conserve de sardine, liqueurs, couscous etc.), une activité qui lui procure des revenus lui permettant de subvenir à ses besoins. Julienne vend également des liqueurs, de façon secondaire. C’est à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin que Julienne s’approvisionne. Mais Julienne vend ses produits dans sa boutique à Cotonou. Julienne est une ancienne cliente de ALIDé qui rembourse bien ses crédits. Malgré la passion qu’elle a pour son activité, Julienne ne dispose pas suffisamment de moyens financiers pouvant lui permettre de faire face à la nombreuse demande de sa clientèle. C’est au vue de cela que Julienne sollicite un autre crédit auprès de ALIDé.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Achat de cartons de lait, conserves, sardines,  mayonnaises,  couscous, et bidons d'huile d'arachide etc.

loans.name: Maria Goreth

texts.pt:
Maria Gorethi Bassamandla M. nasceu no Distrito da Manhiça, Provincia de Maputo, sul de Moçambique, tem 40 anos de idade, solteira e mae de 3 filhos de 21, 13 e 11 anos de idade, todos vaõ a escola. Fez 10ą classe e 2 anos de formação de Professores. Vive na casa propria com os seus filhos, e sustenta a mae enviando generos alimenticios. 

Saiu de Manhiça Para Boane pela transferencia dos serviços, local onde fixou sua residencia e vive neste Distrito ate agora. Trabalha como docente, é do quadro do Ministerio da Educaçaõ amais de 15 anos. Faz cerca de 8 horas de trabalho diariamente, naõ possui nenhum empregado, aufere um salario de 5.565.00mt por més, que aplica nas despesas de casa e ainda poupa algum na sua conta bancaria.

Nunca teve empréstimos em outros bancos, conheceu a Hluvuku através de colegas de serviço que também saõ clientes desta instituição. Este é o seu 3º empréstimo no valor de 12.000.00mt com o qual pretende comprar material de construção (cimento e areia) para rebocar a sua residencia. Os empréstimos anteries foram de 10.000.00mt os dois, ambos para a mesma actividade.

Compromete se a pagar devidamente este emprestimo para poder aceder a outros. No futuro gostaria de solicitar mais empréstimos para concluir a sua residencia para oferecer melhores condições de habitabilidade a sua familia.
texts.en:
Maria Gorethi Bassamandla M. was born in the Manhiça District, Maputo Province, south of Moçambique. She is 40 years old, she is single and she has three children of ages 21,13 and 11. All her children go to school. She went to school until 10th grade and she did 2 years of teaching school. She owns her home, where she lives together with her children and she supports her mom by sending her food. She left from Manhiça to Boane because she got transferred. Here is where she made her home and where she has lived ever since. She has been working as a teacher and has been part of the Education Ministry for more than 15 years. She works for about 8 hours each day, she does not have any employees, she earns a monthly salary of 5.565.00mt which she uses for her home's expenses and she even gets to save a little bit on her bank account. Maria has never had loans in other banks. She heard about Hluvuku through some co-workers who are also clients of this institution. This is her third loan and she is requesting 12.000.00mt which she intends to use to purchase construction material (cement and sand) to put plaster on her home. The other loans she requested in the past were of 10.000.00mt each, both for these same activity. She promises to pay this loan so that she can access further loans. In the future she would like to be able to request more loans to finish her home and offer her family better living conditions.

Translated from Portuguese by Yael Schwartzman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purcahse construction material

loans.name: Rose

texts.en:
Rose Rebote is one of the assets of the ASHI Antique South Branch. Since her membership, she has shown exemplary performance in her repayment, attendance at every weekly center meeting and in her business.  

Despite poverty she worked hard to maintain her fish-selling business to support her payments to ASHI for the loan she had taken. The profit she makes is used to finance the needs of her family and for improving their standard of living. Her determination to send her children to school until they graduate from college is what other members admired the most. 

With her husband’s support in achieving her dreams for their four children, whose ages are from 11 to 16 years old, Rose is requesting another loan from Kiva through its field partner in the Philippines, ASHI. This loan will be used to purchase a new motorized fishing boat to be managed by her husband. Through that, the volume of fish she will sell will increase and her business will grow a little more.

loans.use: To purchase a motorized fishing boat.

loans.name: Maritess

texts.en:
Maritess A. is from the village of Agusan Canyon, Manolo Fortich Bukidnon. She is 35 years old. Maritess is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, she owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop, selling both food and daily use products in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately $220 a month from these activities.

In 2008, Maritess joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation by engaging in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 14,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Maritess is requesting a new loan of 17,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be her 5th loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Annaliza

texts.en:
Annaliza S. is from the village of Talakag, Bukidnon. She is 38 years old. Annaliza is married and has seven school-aged children. To make a living, she owns and operates a business, selling seafood products including fish and shrimp in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately $110 a month from these activities.

In 2009, Annaliza joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Annaliza is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be her 2nd loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to continue to improve her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Leticia's Group

texts.en:
Leticia S. is from the town of Silauan Norte, Echague. She is 46 years old. Leticia is the group leader of a 5-member group loan offered by ASKI/Kiva. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Leticia S. Group.

Leticia is married and has 3 adult-aged children. She owns and operates a general store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Leticia has been involved in her business for over 15 years and earns approximately 4000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2005, Leticia joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Leticia has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8000 PHP from ASKI, which was used to purchase additional products to sell. Leticia is requesting a new loan, her fifth, of 9000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: W. Hortense Léocadie

texts.fr: K. W. Hortense Léocadie est née le 03 Février 1963 et est mariée à HOUNDEFO Paul, un transitaire. Le couple a un enfant qui est scolarisé et qui vit avec eux au quartier Agla à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. C'est depuis 6 ans qu'ils se sont installés dans ce quartier. Le couple supporte ensemble les charges familiales. Hortense Léocadie a arrêté les classes au cours secondaire. Depuis 5 ans, pour subvenir à ses besoins et à ceux de ses enfants, Hortense Léocadie vend du charbon de bois et également des vivres (maïs, haricot, etc.) au marché de Agla. De façon secondaire, Hortense Léocadie vend de l'huile d'arachide. Hortense Léocadie s'approvisionne à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin, et aussi à Parakou dans le Nord du Bénin. Hortense Léocadie a déjà obtenu deux crédits auprès de ALIDé, crédits qui ont été bien remboursés et qui lui ont permis d'élever le niveau de son activité. Hortense Léocadie ambitionne devenir grossiste et donc agrandir davantage son activité. Pour ce faire, Hortense Léocadie sollicite un troisième crédit auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
W. Hortense Léocadie K. was born February 3, 1963 and is married to Paul HOUNDEFO, a forwarding agent. The couple has one child who is in school, and lives with them in the Agla neighborhood of Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. They settled in this area six years ago. The couple share household expenses. Hortense Léocadie interrupted her schooling at secondary level. For the past five years, Hortense Léocadie has been selling charcoal and also food products (corn, beans, etc.) at the Agla market. She also sells peanut oil as a secondary activity. She gets her supplies from Dantokpa, Benin’s international marketplace, but also from Parakou, in the northern part of Benin. Hortense Léocadie has already been granted two loans from ALIDé, both repaid in full, which allowed her to increase her level of activity. She wants to become a wholesaler and therefore expand her business. To accomplish this, she is requesting a third loan from ALIDé.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy 100-kilo bags of corn and charcoal

loans.name: Rosalie

texts.en:
Rosalie M. is from the village of Talakag, Bukidnon. She is 28 years old. Rosalie is married and has four school-aged children. To make a living, she owns and operates a business selling seafood products including fish and shrimp in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over a year and earns approximately $153 a month from these activities.

In 2009, Rosalie joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Rosalie is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be her 2nd loan from HSPFI. loans.name: Gloria's Group

texts.en:
Gloria A. is from the village of San Jose, Norte 1. She is 49 years old. Gloria is the group leader of a 7-member group loan offered by ASKI/Kiva. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Gloria A.'s group.

Gloria is married and has 2 school-aged children. She owns and operates a business raising livestock. The main source of income for the business comes from raising pigs for fattening and sale. Gloria has been involved in her business for over 1 year and earns approximately 3,000 PHP when she sells an animal.

In 2009, Gloria joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Gloria has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from ASKI, which was used to purchase livestock to raise and eventually sell. Gloria is requesting a new loan, her third, of 10000 PHP which will be used to purchase livestock feed and other supplies. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase livestock feed and other supplies

loans.name: Sylvia

texts.en:
Sylvia L. is one of the very active members of ASHI. She is 50 years of age and is blessed with four loving and supportive children whose age range is from 11 to 24 years old. Despite poverty and a difficult way of surviving, Sylvia still feels happy and courageous because of the love and inspiration her husband (named Joyce) gives her all the time. He works as a village policeman and is receiving a small honorarium every month. They would not have been able to cover the expenses of their children if not for Sylvia’s small business. She joined ASHI, a Kiva field partner in the Philippines, and thereafter she had the opportunity to request loans which enable her to support and grow her sweetened-peanut and sweetened-cashew nut-selling business. 

Sylvia started with this business by selling the nuts herself in the market, but she was making only a small profit. Her customers were not as regular as before and were not purchasing large amounts of her product. After several times of receiving loans in increasing amounts through ASHI, Sylvia’s volume of production increased and her business became capable of supplying the demands of her customers. 

She wants to expand even further, especially now that she is supplying three stall owners in the market who sell “pasalubong”, which in the English language means a souvenir or homecoming present (a Filipino cultural tradition). Consequently, Sylvia would like to request a much larger loan this time from Kiva through ASHI. 

The proceeds from her business will be spent for her children’s education, which is the only reason for her continued determination. Sylvia believes that through her business the lives of her children will be different from hers and her husband’s.

loans.use: To buy large volumes of peanut and cashew nuts to sell.

loans.name: Khaled

texts.en: Khaled is a 48-year-old man who lives in Beirut, the capital of Lebanon, with his wife and their four children. He has been working as a blacksmith, producing metal pistons and cold cutters for over 30 years. When he first started his business, he didn’t have difficulties because there is a high demand for his work in the region. He decided on this business because he took over his father’s business. This is the first loan he has requested from Al Majmoua, and he wants to purchase pressure piston pipes for his work. His clients are traders. In the future, he plans to keep on improving his work.

loans.use: To purchase pressure piston pipes for his work.

loans.name: Wellars

texts.en:
Wellars is 26 years old and is single. He lives with his parents in the Gasabo district of Kigali, the capital of Rwanda.

Wellars has been a businessman for three years, selling onions, nuts, tomatoes and so on. He has chosen this kind of business because these products are needed by everyone who is going to cook, and they are more profitable than another foodstuffs.

Wellars is a hardworking man, his business is open from eight in the morning to eight in the evening every day. His business is located in the Kimironko market not far from Rwanda’s international airport. Actually, his business is very organized as well as employing one person as a helper so that his business runs well.

Now, Wellars is requesting a loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company in order to purchase more vegetables to attract more customers. With this added attraction, he will be able to obtain more profits which will allow him to become a wholesaler.

loans.use: To purchase more vegetables to sell

loans.name: Léonie

texts.fr: Née le 30 Décembre 1966 à Covè au Bénin, W. Léonie vit depuis 25 ans au quartier Fidjrossè Kpota à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Mariée à VIDJO Marcel un géomètre, Léonie est mère de quatre enfants, tous scolarisés. Léonie a en plus de ses enfants, deux autres enfants à charge. Le couple assure ensemble les charges de la famille. Pour faire face à ses différentes charges, Léonie vend des tissus et des céréales. Léonie s’approvisionne à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. Il y a près de 20 ans que Léonie mène cette activité. C’est une bonne cliente de ALIDé, qui rembourse bien ses crédits. Léonie voudrait agrandir son activité et mieux répondre à la demande de sa clientèle, ce qui lui permettra de se faire plus de revenu. C’est la raison pour laquelle Léonie sollicite un autre crédit auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
Born December 30, 1966 in Cové (Benin), Léonie W. has been living for the past 25 years in the Fidjrossè Kpota neighborhood of Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. Married to Marcel VIDJO, a surveyor, Léonie is the mother of four children, all attending school. She also has two other children under her care. The couple share household expenses. To meet her various responsibilities, Léonie has been selling pieces of fabric and grain for the past 20 years.. She gets her supplies from Dantokpa, Benin’s international marketplace. Léonie is a good member of ALIDé, and promptly repays her loans. She would like to expand her business in response to customer demand, which will enable her to increase her profits. For this reason, Léonie is requesting another laon from ALIDé.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy pieces of fabric

loans.name: Obiya East A Laker Barbra Group

texts.en:
L. Barbra is a group representative; she is a twenty-one-year-old businesswoman, married with two children. She takes care of three additional dependents who go to school. 

She has a used clothing business that she has been operating for a period of three years now. She is using the loan to purchase clothes from different places to sell to her customers. She hopes to improve upon her business.

loans.use: To purchase clothes from different places to sell to her customers.

loans.name: Beauty

texts.en:
Dried fish in Nigeria is an essential ingredient in the preparation of local soup like egusi (Melon soup). The demands for dried fish are high in Nigeria. 

Beauty sells dried fish to make a living in Sapele. She loves this business because of the one-on-one interaction that she has with her customers. She sells her dried fish in the market. She hopes for a loan amount of 50,000 NGN to purchase more dried fish to sell. 

She is 41 years old, married to a carpenter, and they have four children. Her youngest child is 14 years old. Her children are still dependent on her and they all attend school. Beauty says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more dried fish to sell.

loans.name: Elmer

texts.en:
Elmer M. is from the village of Kauswagan, Cagayan de Oro City. He is 50 years old. Elmer is married and has five adult-aged children. He owns a sari-sari (variety) retail shop where his wife manages the selling of both food and daily use products.  He has been engaged in this business for over five years and earns approximately $135 a month from this activity. Elmer works as a mechanic in a certain motor store in the local community.

In 2009, Elmer joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Elmer has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Elmer is requesting a new loan of 11,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be his 3rd loan from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated to further improve the business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to invest in expanding the business

location.town: Kauswagan, Cagayan de Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Omid Karema Group

texts.en:
This is Omid Karema group which has four members. The group leader is Omid who lives in 11th district of Khir Khana, Kabul, Afghanistan.

Omid is 54 years old and has three children who are in school. He wants to take a loan for his metal shop because he wants to make it larger. 

Karema wants to take a loan for her carpet-weaving business to increase her business, and Sarya wants to take a loan for her business sewing quilts. She wants to have more clients in her business. Also, Abdul W. wants to take a loan for his taxi business. He wants to purchase a new machine for it.

They each want to expand and progress their business and together have requested a group loan of 40,000 Afghani. They would like to thank both AFS and Kiva lenders that support people around the world through their effective process.

loans.use: To enlarge his metal shop

loans.name: Jon-Jon's Group

texts.en:
Jon-jon T. is from the village of Rizal. He is 34 years old. Jon-jon is the group leader of a 9-member group loan offered by ASKI/Kiva. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Jon-Jon T.'s Group.

Jon-jon is married and has 5 school-aged children. He owns and operates a specialized retail store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling seafood products, including fish and shrimp, in the local community. Jon-jon has been involved in his business for over 16 years and earns approximately 8,000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2009, Jon-jon joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Jon-jon has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from ASKI, which was used to purchase additional products to sell. Jon-jon is requesting a new loan, his third, of 15000 PHP which will be used to purchase new items to expand product offering. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand his business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase new items to expand product offering

loans.name: Julie

texts.en:
Julie loves clothes and that is why she sells them. She has been in this business for four years. She hopes for a loan of N50,000 to purchase more clothes to sell.

Julie is a hardworking woman and she hopes to lift her business and family above poverty. She hopes to own a world class boutique in the future.

Julie is 30 years old and married with a child. Her husband is a civil servant and he also supports the home. Julie says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more clothes to sell

loans.name: Lolita

texts.en: Lolita Z. is from the village of Baluarte, Tagoloan, Misamis Oriental. She is 42 years old, is married, and has five adult children. She is shown in the photo with her infant child. Lolita owns and operates a specialized retail store, selling cellphone electronic loads, processed food and thirst quenchers like ice candy, ice water and soft drinks in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month. In 2010, Lolita joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding her business. This loan will be her first from HSPFI. Lolita plans to use the additional revenue generated from her business to improve and expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding her business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Buy yams and plantain bananas

loans.name: C. Sophie

texts.fr: Née en 1971 à Gbokpa, D. C. Sophie vit depuis près de 15 ans au quartier Fidjrossè à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Sophie est mariée à ATINKPEDJO Benoît, un mécanicien, et est mère de deux enfants, tous scolarisés. Sophie apporte une aide à son mari en ce qui concerne les différentes charges de la famille. N'ayant jamais été à l'école, Sophie s'est très tôt mise dans le commerce de produits vivriers. Sophie vend en effet à son domicile, du maïs, du riz et de la farine de manioc. C'est au marché Houègbo et à Adja au Mono, que Sophie se ravitaille. Sophie a déjà près de 30 ans d'expérience dans l'exercice de son activité. C'est une ancienne cliente de ALIDé, qui a bien remboursé les crédits qu'elle avait obtenu de ALIDé. Sophie sollicite un autre crédit en vue de reconstituer le stock de ses produits et de mieux faire face aux besoins des clients.
texts.en:
Born in 1971 in Gbokpa, C. Sophie D. has been living for the past 15 years in the Fidjrossè neighborhood of Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. Sophie is married to Benoît ATINKPEDJO, a mechanic, and is the mother of two children. Sophie helps her husband with the household expenses. As she never attended school, she began retailing food products at an early age. In fact Sophie has been selling corn, rice, and cassava flour from her home for the past 30 years. She gets her supplies from the Houègbo market and from the Adja plateau in Mono Province. She is a regular client of ALIDé, and has repaid in full all previously granted loans. She is now requesting another loan to restock her supplies and face up to customer demand.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy 100-kilo bags of rice and corn

loans.name: Millicent

texts.en: Miilicent W. K. is 37 years old and single, with one child, 17 years old. Her business, known by the name Bimas, is located in a commercial building on Mama Ngina Sreet in the central business district of Kenya's capital city, Nairobi. She has been selling pesticides, acaricides and other agrochemicals to farmers for the last two years. She says that this business is profitable. Her major challenge is that her products are not bought throughout the year due to the seasonal nature of farming. However, she works very hard to keep her business going well. Before starting this business, Miilicent worked for Coopers, a company which specializes in selling agrochemicals. She left that job and currently works for British American Insurance. She is using her loan of KES 50,000 to buy more agrochemicals to expand her business. She hopes to open more outlets all over the country. She also hopes to study and join the best university in Kenya.  She is very hardworking, determined, ambitious and outgoing.

loans.use: pesticides and acaricides

loans.name: Nanssi

texts.en:
Nanssi is a 31 year old woman who lives in Beirut, the capital of Lebanon, with her husband and their three children.

Nanssi sells Tupperware (she actually buys them, and then resells them). Before, her loan, her husband helped her with her Tupperware expenses, but now she wants to increase her sales and that is why she is taking a loan.

This is the first time Nanssi has requested a loan from Al Majmoua in order to purchase Tupperware and increase her sales. Her clients are mainly her friends and neighbors, and also sometimes some mini-markets. She decided on starting her business because she wanted to be financially independent and also supplement her husband’s income.

In the future, Nanssi plans to keep on improving her work... and why not one day opening her own Tupperware shop?

loans.use: To purchase more Tupperware to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Buy pagne cloth for sewing

loans.name: Basema

texts.en: Basema is a 44 year old woman who lives with her husband in Beirut, capital of Lebanon.  Basema has been working as a seamstress. She produces clothes and also repairs all type of clothing. She learned the business when she was young from her mother who also worked as a seamstress. She went into this business in order to help support her husband. Her clients are her friends and neighbors. She requested a loan from Al Majmoua to purchase thread and repair her sewing machine in order to help her husband and improve their situation . This is her third loan and she has always paid on time.

loans.use: To purchase thread and repair her sewing machine.

loans.name: Elias' Group

texts.en: Elias R. Sr. is from the village of La Suerte, Angadanan, Isabela. He is 57 years old. Elias is the group leader of a 19-member group loan offered by ASKI, a Kiva partner. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. Elias is married and has nine adult children. To make a living, Elias runs a general store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling both food and daily-use products in the local community. Elias has been engaged in his business for over 10 years and earns approximately 2,500 Philippine pesos a month for these activities. In 2010, Elias joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Elias is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional inventory and working capital. This will be the first loan taken out by Elias from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand his business. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and working capital

loans.name: Antwaan

texts.en: Antwaan is a 49 year old single man who lives in Beirut, capital of Lebanon. Antwaan has owned and operated a grocery store from where he sells canned food, candies, home cleaning products, rice and pasta, coffee and other items. He also sells fruits and vegetables like tomatoes, lettuce, cucumber, and oranges, bananas, etc. He requested a loan from Al Majmoua in order to purchase merchandise for his store. This is his first loan request from Al Majmoua. His clients are his friends and neighbors. When he first started his business, he did not face many difficulties. In the future, he plans to keep on improving his business.

loans.use: To purchase merchandise for his store.

loans.name: Dionisia

texts.en:
Dionisia C. is from the village of Talakag , Bukidnon. She is 51 years old. Dionisia is married and has 4 school-aged children. To make a living, Dionisia owns & operates a business venture in the retail sector running a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling both food & daily use products in the local community. Dionisia has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 4000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Dionisia joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Dionisia is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the 1st loan taken out by Dionisia from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to support needs of relatives and other family members. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Leopord

texts.en:
Leopord was born in 1982, is single, and takes care of three dependents. He lives with his parents in the Gasabo district of Kigali in the village called Remera. Leopord supports his parents which is the reason why he has to work hard in order to suppy the basic needs of his family.

Leopord owns a small shop which sells different kinds of products such as necklaces for men and women, toys for children, and so on. His business is open from six in the morning to ten in the evening every day, even during the weekend. He employs one person from the community in his shop as a helper.

Thanks to the demand, which is increasing very fast, Leopord is requesting a loan from KIva lenders via Vision Finance Company in order to purchase more products so that he is able to satisfy his customers. He plans to get married when the level of profits he expects to earn is reached.

loans.use: To purchase more products to sell

loans.name: Maryanne

texts.en:
Maryanne W. M. is 38 years old. She is single and has two children aged 14 and 10 years old.

Maryanne has a safaricom M-PESA (money transfer) shop which provides money transfer services to the local people. Her business is located at Juja, a business market in Thika. Thika is the region in Kenya known for production of pineapples.

Maryanne says that this business is profitable and the only major challenge she has is that there are very many people in the area doing the same kind of business as hers, hence customers are spoilt for choice. However, she works very hard to keep her business doing well.

She will use her loan of 50000 KES to increase her float to enable her serve more people. In the future, she hopes to open more M-PESA outlets to serve a larger market and become the market leader in this kind of business. She is a very hardworking and innovative lady.

loans.use: Increase float.

loans.name: Ali

texts.en:
Ali is a 37 year old man who lives in Tyre southern Lebanon with his wife and their two children. Ali has been working in construction since 2004. When he first started his business, he didn’t have enough cash to purchase all the needed tools. He went into this business because he wanted to be financially independent. His clients are his friends and neighbors. 

He requested a loan from Al Majmoua in order to purchase tools and machines for his work. This is the first time that he has requested a loan. In the future, he plans on improving his business by purchasing more sophisticated tools.

loans.use: To purchase tools.

loans.name: Trinidad

texts.en:
Trinidad C. is from the village of  Talakag, Bukidnon. She is 53 years old. Trinidad is married and has 7 school-aged children. To make a living, Trinidad owns & operates a business venture in the food sector making & selling food. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling snacks & other delicacies in the local community. Trinidad has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 4000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Trinidad joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Trinidad is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. This loan will be the 1st loan taken out by Trinidad from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase raw ingredients needed to make food products for sale

loans.name: Léa

texts.fr: Née en 1966 à Savalou, dans le département des Collines, Z. Léa est une veuve et mère de trois enfants, tous scolarisés, dont deux sont à sa charge. Léa vit avec ses enfants au quartier Fidjrossè à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Léa subvient seule aux divers besoins de ses enfants. Léa vend du poisson fris et de l'akassa, met local du Bénin. C'est à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin, et à Porto-Novo, capitale administrative du Bénin, que Léa effectue ses achats. Mais Léa vend ses produits à son domicile. Léa a fréquenté l'école jusqu'au secondaire et excerce son activité depuis maintenant 9 ans. Léa est une cliente fidèle de ALIDé qui rembourse bien ses crédits. Dans le but de redynamiser et   d'élargir son activité, Léa sollicite un autre crédit auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
Born in 1966 in Savalou, in the Collines Department, Léa Z. is a widow and mother of three children. All have had schooling, and two are still under her care. Léa lives with her children in the Fidjrossé neighborhood of Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. She is the sole provider for her children’s needs. Léa sells fried fish and akassa (a food preparation local to Benin) from her home. She gets her supplies from Dantokpa, Benin’s international marketplace, and from Porto-Novo, the administrative capital of Benin. She attended school up to secondary level and has been in business for the past 9 years. She is a regular client of ALIDé, and reimburses well her loans. She is now requesting another loan to expand and invigorate her business.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy fish

loans.name: Florence

texts.en:
Florence sells planks at wholesale and retail prices to her customers in Sapele, Delta State. She sells for long hours to enable her to meet the basic needs of her family members.

Florence is 39 years old and married with four children. Her children are still young and they depend on her. Her husband is a businessman and he also supports the home.

Florence hopes for a loan of N120,000 to purchase more planks to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

Florence is a LAPO client. LAPO (Lift Above Poverty Organization) is committed to improving lives in Nigeria and elsewhere in Africa.

loans.use: To purchase more planks to sell

loans.name: Danilo

texts.en:
Danilo manages a 1-hectare (2.5-acre) rice field in Surallah, South Cotabato and his harvest will reach up to eighty sacks of rice. He is 42 years old with six children, the eldest being 20 years old. He strives hard at his work to let his children finish their studies.

Danilo would like to have additional capital for his business and joined Community Economic Ventures, Inc. because it has a low interest rate. He’s now requesting a loan of Php 15,000 to buy supplies needed for his farm.

loans.use: To buy farm supplies

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Buy alcoholic beverages

loans.name: Jonathan

texts.en:
Jonathan is 40 years old and has a rice-farming business which he started in 1992. He manages a one-hectare (2.5-acre) rice field in Banga, South Cotabato.

Jonathan is the father of two children, his eldest being 8 years old. He wants to help his children to finish their studies by providing them with their needs.

Jonathan lacks capital in his business and that's why he sought help from Community Economic Ventures, Inc., requesting a loan of 8,000 Php. This will enable him to purchase farm supplies.

loans.use: To buy farm supplies

loans.name: Lerma

texts.en:
38-year old Lerma has businesses farming rice and corn and raising hogs. She owns a one-hectare (2.5-acre) rice field and a half-hectare (1.25-acre) corn field. On her last harvest, she harvested forty-eight sacks and fourteen sacks respectively.

Lerma has a 13-year-old child to support and works hard on her farm to be able to sustain her family. This time she's requesting a loan from Community Economic Ventures, Inc. of 15,000 Php. This will help her a lot in providing her farm needs.

loans.use: To buy farm supplies

loans.name: Manuela

texts.en:
Manuela is 53 years old and has a rice-farming business. She has two children in her family and does everything to lift up her family. This is the only way she can provide their needs.

Manuela is now requesting a loan of 8,000 Php to buy seed and supplies for her farm. This loan helps her to continue with her business.

loans.use: To buy seed and other farm inputs

loans.name: Pansheirwat12 Group

texts.en:
Marzya is the group leader of Pansheirwat12 group. There are four female members in this group. They want to develop their businesses. The group leader, Marzya, is 56 years old. She lives with her four children. She wants to take out a loan for her business of quilt-sewing. She wants to buy necessary materials for her business.

Sherowza wants to take a loan for her husband’s general store where he sells different kinds of things. He wants to expand his business and buy more materials, especially the things that are more in demand. He also wants to attract more customers. And Hazar Bibi wants to take a loan for her embroidery business. She wants to expand and further her business.

Leda wants to take a loan for her tailoring business and works hard to earn money for the completion of her family’s requirements. She needs to buy a new sewing machine for her shop because she has lots of problems with the old one she has during sewing. Besides, she wants to hire a student to help her with her business and to enlarge her business.

They are requesting a group loan of 56,000 Afghani. They want to thank all lenders of AFSG and Kiva that help poor people of Afghanistan.

loans.use: To expand and progress their businesses

loans.name: Shirley

texts.en: Shirley T. is from the village of Talakag, Bukidnon. She is 47 years old, is separated from her spouse, and has five adult children. Shirley owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop, selling both food and daily-use products in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over a year and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month. In 2009, Shirley joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Shirley is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding her business. This loan will be her 2nd from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding her business

loans.name: Merilyn

texts.en:
Merilyn is a rice farmer from Banga, South Cotabato. She is 51 years old with six children, her eldest being 27 years old.

Merilyn started managing a rice field back in 1980 and now it reaches to 6 hectares (15 acres). She also has a piggery business. The profit from her farm is the source of income that her family depends on.

Now, Merilyn would like to request a loan of Php 15,000 from Community Economic Ventures, Inc. to expand her farm and supply the necessary materials needed for her rice field and piggery.

loans.use: To buy farm supplies and feed for her pigs

loans.name: Gladys

texts.en:
Gladys is 34 years old, is married to Isaac Njuguna, and they have two school-going children.

For the last fifteen years, Gladys has been sewing clothes to sell in Olkalou town which is in the outskirts of Naivasha town. She has a stable customer base and this ensures that she gets orders for the new clothes in her stall.

Gladys was introduced to KADET by her friend and this will be her first loan. She plans to buy more fabric to make new clothes for sale and also meet the orders she already has from her clientele.

Gladys plans to save and buy a personal vehicle which she will use to go and get her materials from Nairobi which is approximately 150 km away. This will help her save time and money which she currently spends to transport the materials to her place of work.

loans.use: To buy more fabric for her tailoring business

loans.name: Nolita

texts.en:
Nolita supports her family with her hog-raising business, owning five pigs in South Cotabato. She is 50 years old and has three children, her eldest being 24 years old. She is thankful for her business because it sustains the education of her children.

Nolita  is now requesting a loan of Php 10,000 from Community Economic Ventures, Inc. This loan will be very helpful in providing the feeds necessary for her pigs.

loans.use: To buy feed for her pigs

loans.name: Nove

texts.en:
Nove, 35, is living in Surallah, South Cotabato, and has a rice-farming business. He devotes his time to working in his 1-hectare rice field. He heard about Community Economic Ventures, Inc., offering financial support to entrepreneurs like him. He joined CEVI, a Kiva partner, in 2008.

His business is continually growing and now he is requesting a loan of 8,000 Philippine pesos. This amount with a low interest charge will be helpful to sustain his business.

loans.use: Farm supplies

loans.name: Ramon

texts.en:
Ramon, 56, is a rice farmer in Surallah, South Cotabato. He started farming in 1975. Now he manages a 4-hectare rice field. He takes good care of six children in his family. He wants his children to have a bright future; that's why he works hard on the farm in order to provide for their needs.

He joined Community Economic Ventures, Inc., a Kiva partner, in order to seek a loan of 12,000 Philippine pesos. He lacks capital and sought help from CEVI. This loan will help provide fertilizers for his farm.

loans.use: Farm supplies

loans.name: Ritchel

texts.en: Ritchel, 28, is a rice farmer and hog raiser in Surallah, South Cotabato. She has a 7-month old child. She started her business in 2007. She's now requesting a loan from Community Economic Ventures, Inc., a Kiva partner, for 10,000 Philippine pesos. This will enable her to buy farm supplies and feed for her piggery. She manages a 1-hectare rice field and owns one pig. She wants someday to make her business successful.

loans.use: Farm inputs and feeds

loans.name: Roquita

texts.en:
Roquita, 55, is a resident of Surallah, South Cotabato. She started her business selling dried fish but now is a rice farmer. She manages a 4-hectare (10-acre) rice field which is her main source of living. She also operates a passenger bus.

Now, Roquita has six children to support. She lacks capital and that's why she joined Community Economic Ventures, Inc. and requested a loan of 12,000 Php. This loan will help her a lot in providing fertilizer for her rice field and maintenance for her bus.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer for her farm and wheels for her bus

loans.name: Rowena

texts.en:
