El grupo solidario esta conformado por 3 personas, todas tienen diferentes negocios pero de un solo propósito, sus actividades de negocios son las siguientes: Ada S. tiene una tienda de ropa y miscelanea, Argelia A. tiene una venta de ropa y Yesika C. tiene una venta de joyas.

Ada S., tiene 38 años de edad, es casada tiene 4 hijos, 3 de ellos estudian y tiene un bebe de 6 meses, su negocio es de ropa típica y de micelanea, tiene 10 años de tener us negocio, su esoso trabaja y le ayuda con sus gastos y por eso han podido salir adelante. Ada necesita este crédito para ampliar su mercadería, su sueño es ver a sus hijos graduados y poder darles un negocio a cada uno.
texts.en:
This group is comprised of 3 persons, all of whom have different businesses but one purpose. Their business activities are: Ada S. has a clothing and accessories shop; Argelia Ajquil has a clothing store; and Yesika C. has a jewelry store. Ada S. is 38 years old, is married and has 4 children. Three of her children study in school and 1 is a baby of 6 months. Her business of traditional clothing and accessories she has had for 10 years. Her husband works and helps with the expenses and because of this they have been able to get ahead. Ada needs this loan to increase her merchandise. Her dream is to see her children graduate and be able to give them each their own business.

Translated from Spanish by Machelle Wilson, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: invest in merchandise

loans.name: Eva

texts.en: Eva K. is married and has two children. She has completed her senior high school education.  Her husband is a merchant. For some time now, Eva has been selling plastic containers and towels at Abura, near Cape Coast. Eva uses her income to support her husband in the payment of school fees and utility bills.  She will use the loan to purchase more plastic containers and buckets for sale. With the new profits from her expanded business, Eva plans to save to reinvest in the business and to further her children’s education.

loans.use: to purchase more plastic containers and buckets for sale

loans.name: Félix Jose

texts.es: El señor Félix tiene el negocio de panadería, el crédito lo solicita para invertirlo en el mismo y sacar mas producción, el señor Félix antes de tener el negocio era trabajador de otra panadería y después el fue poniendo la de él poco a poco comenzó con un pequeño préstamo y así fue creciendo esto para poder tener mejor ganancia y darle una mejor calidad de vida a su familia, es padre y esposo y todo lo hace por ellos para poder sacarlos adelante.
texts.en:
Felix has a bakery and is asking for this loan to invest in his business and increase production. He worked in another bakery before starting his own. He started little by little, with the help of a small loan, and grew his business in order to increase his income and give a better life to his family. He is a father and a husband and he does it all to help his family get ahead.

Translated from Spanish by Hugo Reyes, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Ingredients

loans.name: Adjoi Marie

texts.fr: Née en 1964, C. Adjoi Marie réside depuis environs 22 ans au quartier Agla à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Adjoi Marie est mariée à DJOSSOU Jean, et est mère de cinq enfants, tous scolarisés. C'est avec ses enfants et son mari que Adjoi Marie vit. Le couple assure ensemble les charges de la famille. Adjoi Marie n'a pas été à l'école. Pour subvenir à ses besoins et à ceux de sa famille, Adjoi Marie fabrique et vend du savon à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin, et aussi dans son quartier. Parallèlement à cette activité, Adjoi Marie vend de l'huile et du maïs. Adjoi Marie s'approvisionne à Dantokpa et au marché de Pahou au Bénin. Adjoi Marie exerce cette activité depuis 15 ans environs et a obtenu auprès de ALIDé, deux crédits qu'elle a eu à bien rembourser. Actuellement Adjoi Marie éprouve de difficultés dans l’approvisionnement de ses produits. C'est la raison pour laquelle Adjoi Marie sollicite un troisième prêt, afin de satisfaire la demande de sa clientèle et aussi d’élargir son champ d’activité.
texts.en:
Born in 1964, Adjoi Marie C. has been living for the past 22 years in the Agla area of Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. Adjoi Marie is married to Jean DJOSSOU, and is the mother of five children, all having had schooling. She lives with her husband and children, and shares family expenses with her husband. She has never been to school herself. To meet her needs and those of her family, Adjoi Marie makes and sells soap in Dantokpa, Benin’s international marketplace, and also in her own neighbourhood. Additionally, she sells oil and corn. She gets her supplies from Dantokpa and from the Pahou market in Benin. She has been doing this for the past fifteen years and has already been granted two loans by ALIDé, both repaid in full. Adjoi Marie is currently experiencing difficulties in obtaining supplies. This is the reason for which she requesting a third loan, to satisfy customer demand and also broaden the scope of her activities.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy caustic soda (to make soap) and containers of oil

loans.name: C2346 Duhozanye Group

texts.en:
Claude was born in 1964 and is married with three children aged between 6 and 16. He lives in the Gasabo district of Kigali province, in the village called Kabuga, not far from Rwanda’s international airport.

Claude owns a small shop which sells various styles of clothes. He chose this business simply because it is profitable in this region. His business is famous which is very stimulating for him. This is his fourth year of successful operation in business! The hours of his shop are from 8 a.m. to 6 p.m. every day, even during the weekend. He works hard so that he satisfies his customers.

Claude is now requesting a loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company in order to expand his business. He will do this through purchasing some other attractive clothing styles for sale as well as additional sizes and colors. With this loan, Claude hopes to attract more customers to shop and hopefully earn more profit in the process.

loans.use: To purchase more clothes to sell

loans.name: Andrea

texts.en:
Andrea is an individual loan client with Esperanza and her story is representative of her group and of Esperanza's Haitian and Dominican (many of whom recently emigrated to the DR from Haiti) clients generally. Her group is located in Hato Mayor, where running water (none of which is potable) and electricity are unreliable. She makes her home here in a simple, wooden structure with her husband and their child.

Andrea is excited to be taking her fifth loan with Esperanza after having successfully repaid her previous loans and expanded her business. Andrea is a very entrepreneurial individual and she plans to use this loan to invest in both of her businesses:the production of "embutidos" (sausages filled with a variety of meats) and selling clothing. She will purchase meats for the embutidos and blouses, jeans and skirts for the clothing business. She will use the profits to invest in her home by replacing the wooden walls with concrete block, creating a more storm- and pest-resistant living situation. She thanks you all for your support.

loans.use: Meats and clothes

loans.name: Emaka

texts.en:
Emaka is a businessman and he loves doing business. He is 24 years old and single without children although he hopes to get married very soon.

Emaka sells women’s shoes at retail prices and sells for long hours to support his aged parents. He hopes to own a shoe factory in the future.

Emaka has a good relationship with LAPO. He is requesting a loan of NGN 150,000 to purchase more women’s shoes to sell. He says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

LAPO (Lift Above Poverty Organization) is committed to improving lives in Nigeria and elsewhere in Africa.

loans.use: To purchase more women's shoes to sell

loans.name: Betty

texts.en:
Betty is 39 years old and married with seven children, ranging in age from 10 to 22 years old.  Six of her children are currently enrolled in school. Betty has been running a mixed farm for over ten years just outside of Kitale, Kenya, in the western region of the country. She sells maize, milk, and cereals as the primary source of her income, while also earning money selling second-hand clothes and blankets in her town. She says that the main challenge right now is occasional bouts of disease spreading through her livestock.

Betty recently completed her first loan with Juhudi Kilimo for KES 30,000, and has now requested this loan for KES 50,000 to expand her stock of poultry and acquire necessary farm supplies. She also wants to use a portion of the loan for school fees for her children, as she repeatedly stresses the importance of education. She says that the extra income from this loan will hopefully enable her to send all of her children through school, and eradicate poverty in her family. In the future, she would like to continually improve on her farming abilities and provide for her extended family.

Betty is thus far very pleased with her association with Juhudi Kilimo/Kiva. She is proud of the changes she has witnessed in her own family and her town, and hopes that one day all of her needs will be met through continued cooperation with Juhudi/Kiva.

loans.use: To buy farm supplies and increase poultry stock

loans.name: Asterio

texts.en:
Asterio M. is 53 years old and married to Anatolia Benitez. They have four kids who are grown up.

Asterio has been in the same line of work for fifteen years. To open his food stall he first had to sell some land that he inherited from his mother and then used the proceeds to buy his first merchandise. Asterio's wife helps him so that the couple can get ahead and hopefully help their children pay for their education.

The loan will be used to purchase food such as rice, sugar, herbs, oil, and noodles. Asterio would like to eventually expand his business.

loans.use: To purchase rice, sugar, herbs, oil, noodles and other foods

loans.name: Akouebavi Justine Esther

texts.fr: A. Akouebavi Justine Esther est née le 04 Novembre 1946. Mariée à MASSAOUDOU Mama, un commerçant, Justine Esther est mère de trois enfants, tous scolarisés. En plus de ses enfants, Justine Esther a deux autres enfants à charge. Il y a une dizaine d'année que Justine Esther s'est installée à Agla, un quartier de Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Justine Esther vit seule avec ses enfants et assure seule leurs charges. Justine Esther a fréquenté l'école jusqu'au cours secondaire. Mais il y a environs 30 ans que Justine Esther mène comme activité, la vente de céréales, d'huile d'arachide et de perles, à son domicile. Justine Esther s'approvisionne à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. Justine Esther est une ancienne cliente de ALIDé, ayant déjà bénéficié de deux prêts qui ont tous été bien remboursés. Justine Esther voudrait élever davantage le niveau de son activité et se faire plus de revenu. Ce revenu  lui servira plus tard à diversifier son activité par l'achat de réfrigérateur en vue de la vente de produits frais. C'est la raison pour laquelle Justine Esther sollicite un troisième cédit auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
Akouebavi Justine Esther A. was born November 4,1946. Married to Mama MASSAOUDOU, a merchant, Justine Esther is the mother of three children, all having had schooling. She also takes care of two other children besides her own. About 10 years ago, Justine Esther settled in the Agla area of Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. She lives alone with her children and is their sole provider. She has never attended school herself. For the past 30 years, Justine Esther has been selling grain, peanut oil and pearls from her home. She gets her supplies from Dantokpa, Benin’s international marketplace. Justine Esther is a long-time client of ALIDé, where she has already been granted two loans, both repaid in full. She would like to increase the level of her activity and generate more income. The profits will be used later to diversify her activities: she will purchase a refrigerator to store fresh produce for sale.This is the reason for which she requesting a third loan from ALIDé.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy bags of rice, jerrtcans of peanut oil, and pearls

loans.name: Mujeres Necesitadas 1 Group

texts.en:
Fidelina is the coordinator of her group 'Mujeres Necesitadas' (Needed Women), and her story is representative of her group and of Esperanza's Dominican and Haitian (many of whom recently emigrated to the DR from Haiti) clients generally. Her group is located in the rural areas surrounding Hato Mayor, a poor, agricultural region, where running water (none of which is potable) and electricity are unreliable. She makes her home here in a simple structure as a single mother with her three children.

Fidelina is excited to be taking her seventh loan with Esperanza after having successfully repaid her previous loans and grown her business. She plans to use this loan to invest in her business selling seafood by purchasing a freezer to keep her products longer, as well as merchandise to sell, including lobster, shrimp, and fish.

She will use the profits to invest in her family by purchasing shoes for her children as well as a motorcycle for transportation and a computer for her children to learn on. Additionally, she will invest in her home by adding a kitchen. Finally, she would like to save enough to add a clothing aspect to her business. Obviously, she is has high hopes for the future and she thanks you all for your support.

loans.use: Seafood to sell and a refrigerator

loans.name: Mavis

texts.en: Mavis B. sells fried fish at Abura, Cape Coast. Mavis has received junior high education. She is married and has three children. Her husband is a driver. Mavis has been selling fried fish for some time now. She helps her husband in the payment of school fees and utility bills. Her loan will be used to buy more fresh fish to fry for sale. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to reinvest into that business.

loans.use: Her loan will be used to buy more fresh fish to fry for sale

loans.name: Flor De Pascua Group

texts.es:
El grupo solidario conformado por tres socias, Albertina C., tiene una venta de tortillas y venta de refacciones, Milva Alicia, una tienda de ropa y micelanea, Sara tiene una panadería.
Sara tiene 40 años de edad, vive en Patzun; tiene 7 hijos, de los cuales 1 ya esta casado, 2 graduados y 4 estudiando, su negocio es una panadería, sus hijos la ayudan, ella vende 3 días a la semana los días de mercado. Tiene 20 años de tener su negocio, con la ayuda de su esposo ha podido superarse y ahora tiene la necesidad de adquirir un crédito para poder comprar la materia prima; ya que se acerca la Semana Santa, (tradición en Guatemala) para muchos es costrumbre la compra de pan, y es cuando su negocio tiene demanda. El sueño de Sara es darles una casa a sus hijos y una mejor vida.
texts.en:
This group is comprised of three partners: Albertina C., who has a tortilla shop and also sells spare parts; Milva Alicia has a clothing and accessories store; and Sara has a bread shop. Sara is 40 years old, lives in Patzun. She has 7 children of whom one is already married, 2 have graduated and 4 are studying in school. Her business is a bread shop and her children help. She sells 3 days a week on market days. She has had her business for 20 years. With the help of her husband she has been able to overcome and now has the need to acquire a loan to be able to buy raw materials. As Easter week approaches (an important festival in Guatemala) for many it is the custom to buy a lot of bread, and so her business has a high demand. Sara’s dream is to give a house to her children and to have a better life.

Translated from Spanish by Machelle Wilson, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: raw materials for making bread

loans.name: Emiline

texts.en:
Emiline F. is a devoted mother to her three children. She is married to her loving spouse, Joel F., a mechanical maintenance man, and lives in the beautiful province of Teresa, Rizal. She and her husband are engaged in a farming business and also operate a general store. Despite many challenges in their life, they never give up the fight against poverty.

She plans to utilize this loan of Php 45,000 to expand her farming business and to support her general store as their primary source of daily income. This loan will be used for additional capital for her farming business and half of the money will be used to pay for groceries for her general store.

During her 5 years at ASHI, she has shown very good performance as a member, and she is trusted by ASHI for her solid record. Aside from maintaining an excellent performance in repayment, business, and attendance in ASHI, Emiline has also cared for the needs of her children at home and in school.

This loan will enable her to finally reach her dreams in life: to have a growing business, a good life, and a happy family as well. She hopes the loans from ASHI, KIVA's field partner will support the education of all her children.  She believes that her business will help her family to rise up and fight against poverty, as well as provide for the educational needs of her children. She is very grateful to ASHI and KIVA for the continuous love and support of her dreams.

loans.use: to expand her farming business and to support her general store

loans.name: Fuente De Bendiciion Group

texts.en:
Reina is the coordinator of her group 'Fuente D. Bendicion' (Source of Blessing), and her story is representative of her group and of Esperanza's Dominican and Haitian (many of whom recently emigrated to the DR from Haiti) clients generally. Her group is located in the rural areas surrounding Hato Mayor, a poor, agricultural area where running water (none of which is potable) and electricity are unreliable. She makes her home here in a simple structure with her long-term partner.

Reina is excited to be taking her fourth loan with Esperanza after having successfully repaid her previous loans and grown her business. She plans to use this loan to invest in her business by purchasing merchandise to sell including fish and shrimp. She will use the profits to invest in her future by saving towards going to university after she finishes her high school courses and inves in her home by purchasing a plot of land on which to construct her own home. She thanks you all for your support.

loans.use: buying fish and shrimp to sell

loans.name: Hawa

texts.en:
Hawa A. sells second-hand clothes at Abura near Cape Coast. Hawa has received senior high education. She is married and has five dependents. Her husband is a driver.

Hawa has been selling second-hand clothes for some time now. She helps her husband in the payment of school fees and utility bills. Her loan will be used to buy second-hand clothes for sale. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to educate her children.

loans.use: buy second-hand clothes for sale

loans.name: Hubertine Amélie

texts.fr: Née en 1982 à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin, K. Hubertine Amélie est mariée à SOSSOU Albert, un transitaire. Le couple a quatre enfants, tous scolarisés. La famille réside au quartier Agla à Cotonou, depuis environs 11 ans. Le couple assure ensemble les charges familiales. Hubertine Amélie n'a fréquenté que l'école primaire. Pour assurer les différentes charges qui lui incombent, Hubertine Amélie   vend des tissus et divers autres produits (riz, produits cosmétiques, etc.) à son domicile. Hubertine Amélie s'approvisionne à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. C'est depuis 15 ans que Hubertine Amélie exerce cette activité, et elle a déjà obtenu deux crédits qu'elle a bien remboursés auprès de ALIDé. Hubertine Amélie souhaite augmenter davantage le stock de ses produits et mieux répondre aux différents besoins de ses clients. Cependant, Hubertine Amélie ne réunit pas assez de fonds pour renforcer son activité. C’est pourquoi Hubertine Amélie sollicite auprès de ALIDé, un troisième crédit.
texts.en:
Born in 1982 in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin, Ms. K. Hubertine Amélie is married to Mr. SOSSOU Albert, a shipping agent.  The couple have four children who are all in school.  The family has been residing in the Agla district in Cotonou for eleven years.  The couple jointly ensure that family expenses are covered.  Hubertine Amélie attended primary school only.  To meet the different responsibilities incumbent upon her, she sells cloth and a variety of other goods (rice, cosmetics, etc.) out of her home.  She gets her supplies at Dantokpa, the international market of Benin, and has been in this business for fifteen years.  She has already obtained two loans, which she has repaid to ALIDé.  She would like to augment further her inventory of goods and to respond better to the different needs of her customers.  However, she hasn't gathered enough funds for bolstering her business.  This is why she's requesting a third loan from ALIDé.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying cloth, cosmetics, etc.

loans.name: Sergio Alberto

texts.es:
El Sr. Sergio E. tiene un pequeño establecimiento de billar en su casa de habitación además de vender golosinas, hielo, gaseosas, popsicles, pan dulce y simple, etc. 
El va a utilizar este crédito en la compra de varias cajillas de gaseosas, golosinas, pan para surtir más su negocio.
Antes de tener su propio establecimiento él trabajaba como asalariado, fue ahí donde ahorro dinero y compro las 2 mesas de billar que hoy en día son las que le traen el sustento diario a su casa, además de la venta de gaseosas, pan, hielo, popsicles, etc. Que todos los días vende.
El espera que surtiendo el negocio de las gaseosas,  pan y golosinas le ayuden mucho porque tendrá más ingresos  en su negocio.
Este es el segundo crédito que tiene con CEPRODEL, y el dijo que sus créditos le han ayudado mucho a crecer en su negocio y en su vida familiar.
texts.en:
Sergio runs a small billiard hall in his home. He also sells sweets, ice, soft drinks, popsicles, breads, etc. He will use the money from this loan to buy cases of soft drinks, treats, and breads so that he can have a variety to offer. Before he started his own business, he worked as a salaried employee, which is how he was able to save the money to buy two billiard tables, which now bring a daily income into his home, aside from his sale of the snacks. He hopes that the variety of soft drinks and snacks will help him increase his revenue. This will be his second loan thought CEPRODEL and he tells us that the loans have helped him grow his business and have helped his family life.

Translated from Spanish by Hugo Reyes, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy soft drinks and snacks for resale

loans.name: Faith

texts.en: Faith is 35 years old and she is married with a child. Her child is 16 years old and attends school. Her husband is a commercial driver and he also supports the home. She is hard-working woman and she hopes to lift her business and family above poverty. She sells gari (cassava flakes) at retail prices to her customers. Gari is a staple food in Nigeria and the demand for it is high. She hopes for the loan amount of NGN 80,000 to purchase more gari to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more gari (cassava flakes) to sell

loans.name: Lucy

texts.en: Lucy Q. sells building materials such as plywood, nails, and roofing sheets at Abura near Cape Coast.  Lucy has received senior high education.  She is married and has three children. Her husband is a teacher. Lucy has been selling building materials for some time now. She helps her husband in the payment of school fees and utility bills. Her loan will be used to buy more building materials for sale. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy more building materials for sale

loans.name: Jocelyn

texts.en:
Jocelyn B. is a 34-year-old woman from the mountainous town of Antipolo, Rizal Province in the Philippines. She is still single but looking for the right man to comfort her when she becomes older. She is grateful to ASHI for offering her happiness in life and group support in achieving her goals.

In 2008, Jocelyn joined ASHI (Ahon Sa Hirap, Inc.), an MFI and KIVA partner in the Philippines. When she received her previous loans, she invested the money in buying and selling small items and later expanded the business with more stock.

Now on her 3rd loan, she requested 15,000 pesos as additional working capital for her business. She is positive that her business will grow since she already has regular customers placing orders with her.

She dreams of having a permanent space in the marketplace where she can sell her products. Her dreams are to build her own durable, concrete house and purchase her own land. She hopes to have a successful business that can provide her with a good life that is far away from poverty.

NOTE: Please disregard the date appearing on the photo. The camera's internal date was not set correctly.

loans.use: additional working capital for her business

loans.name: Hubertine Amélie

texts.fr: Née en 1982 à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin, K. Hubertine Amélie est mariée à SOSSOU Albert, un transitaire. Le couple a quatre enfants, tous scolarisés. La famille réside au quartier Agla à Cotonou, depuis environs 11 ans. Le couple assure ensemble les charges familiales. Hubertine Amélie n'a fréquenté que l'école primaire. Pour assurer les différentes charges qui lui incombent, Hubertine Amélie   vend des tissus et divers autres produits (riz, produits cosmétiques, etc.) à son domicile. Hubertine Amélie s'approvisionne à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. C'est depuis 15 ans que Hubertine Amélie exerce cette activité, et elle a déjà obtenu deux crédits qu'elle a bien remboursés auprès de ALIDé. Hubertine Amélie souhaite augmenter davantage le stock de ses produits et mieux répondre aux différents besoins de ses clients. Cependant, Hubertine Amélie ne réunit pas assez de fonds pour renforcer son activité. C’est pourquoi Hubertine Amélie sollicite auprès de ALIDé, un troisième crédit.
texts.en:
Née en 1982 à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin, K. Hubertine Amélie est mariée à SOSSOU Albert, un transitaire. Le couple a quatre enfants, tous scolarisés. La famille réside au quartier Agla à Cotonou, depuis environs 11 ans. Le couple assure ensemble les charges familiales. Hubertine Amélie n'a fréquenté que l'école primaire. Pour assurer les différentes charges qui lui incombent, Hubertine Amélie vend des tissus et divers autres produits (riz, produits cosmétiques, etc.) à son domicile. Hubertine Amélie s'approvisionne à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. C'est depuis 15 ans que Hubertine Amélie exerce cette activité, et elle a déjà obtenu deux crédits qu'elle a bien remboursés auprès de ALIDé. Hubertine Amélie souhaite augmenter davantage le stock de ses produits et mieux répondre aux différents besoins de ses clients. Cependant, Hubertine Amélie ne réunit pas assez de fonds pour renforcer son activité. C’est pourquoi Hubertine Amélie sollicite auprès de ALIDé, un troisième crédit.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Achat de tissus, de produits cosmétiques de riz etc.

loans.name: Miguel Wilfrido

texts.es:
Miguel Wilfrido M. G. tiene 66 años, es casado y se dedica a la agricultura.  Vive con su esposa y 4 hijos.  Tiene 6 hijos en total, 2 de ellos están trabajando en Quito.

El socio pertenece a la ventanilla rural "San Jose de las Orquideas" que está ubicada de 15 minutos de la ciudad de San Miguel en la comunidad de San Jose de Palmas.  La gran parte de la comunidad son agricultores y crecen papas y maíz como los principales cultivos.

Miguel siembra maiz y papas en grandes cantidades y tiene otros cultivos que crece solo para consumir.  Tiene una casa propia y 2 cuadras y media de terreno en las que siembra sus cultivos.  Vende todos sus productos en las ferias en la ciudad de San Miguel.  Solicita el crédito para comprar insumos agrícolas.

Su esperanza en la vida es que sus hijos culminen sus estudios, pero no siempre es posible por la situación económica.  Los jovenes a veces tienen que ausentarse para trabajar y ayudar a sus padres en la agricultura.

También Miguel es carpintero aparte de la agricultura.  Hace muebles y puertas para casas y le gusta mucho dedicarse a esta actividad.
texts.en:
Miguel Wilfrido M. G. is 66 and married. He is a farmer. He lives with his wife and four children. They have six children in all; two of them are working in Quito. He belongs to the San Jose de las Orquideas Communal Bank, which is located 15 minutes from the city of San Miguel in the San Jose de Palmas community. Most of the community’s residents are farmers who grow potatoes and corn as their primary crops. Miguel plants corn and potatoes in great quantity. He has other crops that grow solely for consumption. He has his own house and two and a half blocks of land where he plants his crops. He sells his products in the fairs in the city of San Miguel. He is asking for a loan to buy agricultural supplies. His hope in life is that his children finish their education. But, that is not always possible because of the economic situation. Young people sometimes have to miss school in order to work and help their parents with the farming. Miguel is also a carpenter. He makes furniture and doors for houses, and he really likes this work.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy farming supplies

loans.name: Trabajando Para El Futuro 2 & 9 Group

texts.en:
Eladia, 49, is a borrower who lives in Samana, Dominican Republic. She is the coordinator for her group, 'Trabajando Para el Futuro' (Working for the Future), and her story is representative of those in her group and other Dominican and Haitian borrowers at Esperanza International.

Eladia and her husband have three children and live in a simple home in Samana, a city on a peninsula with the same name in the northeastern part of the Dominican Republic. Life in Samana can be rough, with no potable running water, frequent power outages (if one has power to begin with), and inadequate health care. Despite these difficulties, Eladia runs a successful business selling seafood. The area is known for its fishing industry, and since it is a peninsula, the demand for and availability of fish is quite high. With this loan, Eladia will catch and purchase fish, shrimp, and crab to sell for a small profit.

This is Eladia’s ninth loan with Esperanza International. With her profits, she hopes to buy a small boat so she can catch more of her own seafood, giving her a greater profit margin. She also will buy her children school supplies, including notebooks, shoes, and backpacks. With continued investments into her business, Eladia hopes to one day have her own home. With your loan, Eladia will be well on her way to reach these goals.

Esperanza International seeks to free children and their families through initiatives that generate income, education and health, restoring self-worth and dignity to those who have lost hope. We have over 8,500 active associates in eleven offices in the Dominican Republic and Haiti. Thank you for lending to Eladia and the 'Trabajando Para el Futuro' group!

loans.use: Fish, shrimp, and crab to sell for profit

loans.name: Lilia

texts.es:
Lilia, es una mujer muy honesta, vive en el Distrito de Calleria, región Ucayali, tiene 51 años, es madre de ocho hijos y 4 todavía dependen de ella. Lilia se dedica a la costura, esta actividad la realiza en su casa, cuenta con el apoyo de su esposo quien trabaja como estibador. Lilia forma parte del Banco Comunal “Las activas”, desde hace nueve años, el primer crédito que recibió fue de 300 soles, que fue invertido en la compra de telas y materiales para su negocio, ahora ella necesita un crédito de 2000 soles, que será invertido en la compra de telas y en la implementación de su taller de costura.
La meta de Lilia es construir una casa para hacer cuartos y ponerlos en alquiler.
texts.en:
Lilia is a very honest woman. She lives in the Calleria district in the Ucalayi region. She is 51 and has eight children. Four of the children are still dependent upon her. Lilia is a seamstress, and she works at home. She has her husband’s support. He works as a longshoreman. Lilia has been part of the Las Activas Communal Bank for nine years. Her first loan was for 300 PEN, which she used to buy fabric and materials for her business. She now needs a loan for 2,000 PEN. She will use it to buy fabric and to set up her seamstress shop. Lilia’s goal is to build a house, make rooms, and rent them out.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy fabric and to set up her seamstress shop

loans.name: Svitlana

texts.en:
Svitlana is married. She runs a small farming business growing early spring agricultural produce in the town of Gladkovka, Kherson region. Svitlana has been in this business for 10 years. Presently, she has 38,000 Grivnyas invested in this enterprise.

Svitlana is requesting an 8,000 Grivnya loan to purchase polyethylene film, fertilizer, and wire for her greenhouse. She believes her refurbished greenhouse will ensure better protection for her plants. Enhanced plant growth will make her business more profitable, bringing her additional income as a result.

loans.use: to purchase polyethylene film, fertilizer, and wire for her greenhouse

loans.name: Beatrice

texts.en:
Beatrice is 51 years old and married with five children. Beatrice is a hardworking farmer. She plants various types of vegetables on her farm and during harvest time, she sells the vegetables to resellers. She hopes to add more crops to plant on her farm in the future. She loves her farming business because it is lucrative.

She is requesting the loan amount of 100,000 Nigerian naira to purchase more vegetable seedlings to plant. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more vegetable seedlings to plant

loans.name: Novelyn

texts.en:
Novelyn C. is a woman full of determination to rise above poverty. She is 40 years old and is still fighting the challenge of poverty. She is married and the mother of three minor children, all of whom need her continued support. She lives in the coastal town of Cardona in the province of Rizal in the Philippines. 

In 1998, she decided to join Ahon Sa Hirap, Inc. (ASHI), an MFI and Kiva partner in the Philippines, to acquire working capital for her business of making and selling “bukayo,” a sweet delicacy.  As a busy entrepreneur, she also embarked on another business of Buy and selling of pork meat and fish. Both businesses are delivering solid profits.

During her membership in ASHI, Novelyn has achieved strong performance with steady repayments and regular attendance to center meetings. She is requesting a loan of 40,000 pesos to pay for more stock to make sweet delicacies such as coconut, sugar,and other supplies.  Furthermore, the remaining money will use to purchase a second hand tricycle (motorcycle with sidecar).

The loan from Kiva will help Novelyn achieve her goals in life. She wants to help her children with their school fees until they finish college so they can achieve a better quality of life. She is very thankful to ASHI and Kiva for the continued support of her dreams.


About ASHI: Ahon sa Hirap Inc. (ASHI) has the distinction of being the oldest existing replication of Grameen Bank Approach (GBA) to credit delivery to the bottom poor in the Philippines. With its outstanding achievements over the years, it has become one of the role models in credit delivery to the poor in the country.

loans.use: To pay for more stock to make sweet delicacies such as coconut, sugar, and other supplies and remaining fund will use to buy a second hand tricycle (motorcycle with sidecar).

loans.name: Henrietta

texts.en: Henrietta S. D. sells baked bread and cakes in Abura near Cape Coast. S. D. has received a senior high education. She is married and has three children. S. D. has been selling bread for some time now. She supports her husband in the payment of school fees and other family responsibilities. Her loan will be used to buy flour, margarine and other ingredients for baking. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to save to reinvest into the business.

loans.use: To buy flour, margarine and other ingredients for baking

loans.name: Amor Y Amistad 2,3,4 Group

texts.en:
Tanis is the coordinator of her group, Amor y Amistad (Love and Friendship), and her story is representative of her group and of Esperanza's Haitian and Dominican clients (many of whom recently emigrated to the Dominican Republic from Haiti) generally. Her group is located in the Samana peninsula, a lush, rugged area with a nascent tourism industry, where running water (none of which is potable) and electricity are unreliable. She makes her home here in a simple structure with her husband and three children.

Tania is excited to be taking her tenth loan  with Esperanza after having successfully repaid her previous loans and grown her business. She plans to use this loan to invest in her beauty salon by purchasing a basin for washing hair as well as a line of hair products, including shampoo and straighteners. She will use the profits to invest in her children by purchasing food, shoes, pencils and backpacks for them. She would also like to purchase a vehicle. Finally, she would like to invest in her business by securing a locale for it that is in a high traffic area and which is big enough to accommodate an ice cream shop as well. She thanks you all for your support.

loans.use: to purchase a washing basin and hair products

loans.name: Oleg

texts.en:
Oleg is married with two sons. He is a farming entrepreneur from Gladkovka, in south-eastern Ukraine. He owns a greenhouse and grows vegetables for sale in his region. Oleg launched this enterprise 5 years ago. Ever since his business has grown and flourished much. Presently, Oleg has 50,000 Grivnyas invested in this venture. 

Oleg is requesting a 9,000 Grivnya loan to repair his greenhouse and purchase a supply of firewood (acacia and pine wood) to heat his greenhouse. He hopes to make his greenhouse more energy-efficient and is focused on sustainable agriculture. These practices would help him reduce costs and gain higher profit as a result.

loans.use: to do some repairs on his greenhouse and purchase firewood

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Selling children's clothing and women's accessories

loans.name: Olexander

texts.en:
Olexander is married with three children: two boys and a girl. He is a farmer from Gladkovka. Olexander grows early spring agricultural produce for further sale in regional marketplaces. He has been in this business for 20 years. Currently, Olexander has 15,000 Grivnyas invested in this trade.  

Olexander is seeking an 8,000 Grivnya loan to purchase polyethylene film, coir fiber pads, fertilizers and firewood for his greenhouse. He can be characterized as an organized and diligent planner. These natural characteristics have helped him develop his venture and thus provide for his family needs.

loans.use: to purchase polyethylene film, coir fiber pads, fertilizers and firewood for his greenhouse

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy plates, fabrics and toiletries

loans.name: Meylin Del Carmen

texts.es: La señora Meylin tiene el negocio de pulpería ella solicito el crédito para invertirlo en el negocio y así tener mas productos que ofrecerles a sus clientes esto para tener una mayor ganancia e ingresos para su familia, el negocio lo empezó con crédito pequeños y a si lo ha ido incrementando antes de tener el negocio la señora Meylin bordaba trajes típicos, es madre de cuatros niños y es por ellos que la señora desde horas muy tempranas esta atendiendo el negocio esto para mejorar su calidad de vida.
texts.en:
Meylin has a local convenience store. She is requesting a loan to invest into her business and be able to expand on her current stock and obtain a higher income for her family. Meylin started her business with few funds but little-by-little has managed to expand the business. Before starting the business of convenience store, Meylin embroidered traditional costumes. She is mother to four children and this is why Meylin gets up very early in the morning to attend to her business and therefore improve her family’s standard of living.

Translated from Spanish by Justine Raymond, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy rice, sugar, beans, cooking oil and ham.

loans.name: Elisa

texts.en:
Elisa C. is a 33 year-old married woman from Jala-jala, Rizal. She and her husband are blessed to have four children.  A member of the Bayugo center of Ahon Sa Hirap, Inc. (ASHI) Rizal East Branch, Elisa is a very industrious woman determined to achieve a better life.  Despite hardships caused by poverty, Elisa remains strong and dedicated in her pursuit to improve her family’s standard of living. The love and support of her husband make her life quite meaningful.

To earn a living, Elisa buys and sells fish. She has been engaged in this business for two years. She joined ASHI, a microfinance institution and Kiva partner in the Philippines, in 2005. During the course of her membership, she has been an excellent performer with respect to regular attendance at meetings, loan repayment, and projects. She is now seeking her sixth loan, in the amount of 40,000 PHP, to purchase additional inventory of fish.

With access to additional working capital through ASHI and Kiva, Elisa is hopeful that her dreams of sending her children to a university to complete college degrees will be achieved.  She also hopes to build a more durable house made of concrete, and to purchase a car to support her business.  A vehicle will help with customer deliveries and inventory pick-up at the dock.

Elisa’s desire to give her children a brighter future fuels her dedication to her business.

loans.use: to purchase additional inventory of fish

loans.name: Maria Fernanda

texts.es:
Maria Fernanda A. G. tiene 20 años, es soltera y vive con sus padres y 10 hermanos.  Son 11 hermanos en total, 6 mujeres y 5 varones.

La socia pertenece a la ventanilla rural "San Jose de las Orquideas" que está ubicada de 15 minutos de la ciudad de San Miguel en la comunidad de San Jose de Palmas. La gran parte de la comunidad son agricultores y crecen papas y maíz como los principales cultivos.

Maria ayuda a sus padres en la agricultura.  La familia siembra maiz, papas, habas, alverjas, y otros cultivos en pocas cantidades.  Sembraron recién el maiz a fines de enero y piensan cosechar el maiz en el verano.  Hacen las compras y ventas de los productos en las ferias en San Miguel los dias jueves y domingo.  Lo dificil de trabajar en el campo es que a veces las enfermedades y las sequias afectan los cultivos.

Solicita el crédito para invertir en la agricultura para comprar insumos agrícolas.  En en futuro, desea ser profesional en la contabilidad y seguir ayudando a sus padres con los cultivos.

En sus tiempos libres, le gusta escuchar música romántica y pasar tiempo con sus padres.
texts.en:
Maria Fernanda A. G. is 20 years old, single, and lives with her parents and ten siblings. Altogether there are eleven children, six daughters and five sons.

She is a member of the Communal Bank “San Jose de las Orquideas”, which meets in the community of San Jose de Palmas and is located fifteen minutes away from the city of San Miguel. The majority of the residents of this community are farmers who grow potatoes and corn as their main crops.

Maria helps her parents with their farm. Her family grows corn, potatoes, lima beans, peas, and other crops in small quantities. They recently planted corn at the end of January and expect to harvest it in the summer. In addition, they buy and sell products at the fairs in San Miguel on Thursdays and Sundays. The difficulties of having to work in the field involve having to deal with disease and drought that impact the crops.

Maria is requesting a loan to purchase farming supplies. In the future, she wants to become a professional accountant and continue to help parents with their farm.

In her spare time, Maria enjoys listening to romantic music and spending time with her parents.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase agricultural supplies for her parents' farm

loans.name: Rosa Ines

texts.es:
Rosa Inés, es una mujer muy amorosa, vive en el Distrito de Calleria, región Ucayali, tiene 64 años, es madre de tres hijos que ya son independientes, ella se dedica a administrar su bodega, esta actividad la realiza en su casa, actualmente se encuentra separada de su pareja. Rosa Inés forma parte del Banco Comunal “Las activas”, desde hace dos ciclos, el primer préstamo que recibió fue de 300 soles, que fue invertido en la compra de mercaderías para abastecer su bodega.
Ahora ella necesita un crédito de 500 soles, que será invertido en la compra de diversos productos como arroz, azúcar, fideos, etc., para surtir su negocio. La meta de Rosa Inés es ampliar su bodega y seguir trabajando.
texts.en:
Rosa Inés is a loving woman who lives in the District of Calleria, Ucayali Region. She is 64 years old, the mother of three adult children, and currently separated from her partner. Rosa Inés manages a store located in her home. She has been a member of the Communal Bank “Las Activas” (The Active Ones) for the past two loan cycles. Her first loan was in the amount of 300 soles and used to buy merchandise to restock her store.

She is now requesting a loan of 500 soles to purchase different products such as rice, sugar, noodles, and other items to increase her business. Her goals are to expand her store and continue working.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase rice, sugar, noodles, etc.

loans.name: Ruth Y Esther 2 Group

texts.en:
Mariluz, 34, is a borrower who lives in Samana, Dominican Republic. She is the coordinator for her group, Ruth y Esther (Ruth and Esther), and her story is representative of those in her group and other Dominican and Haitian borrowers at Esperanza International.

Mariluz is a single mother of two who lives in a simple home in Samana, a city on a peninsuL. with the same name in the north-eastern part of the Dominican Republic. Life in Samana can be rough, with no potable running water, frequent power outages (if one has power to begin with), and inadequate healthcare. Despite these difficulties, Mariluz runs a successful business selling clothing to her friends and neighbors. With this loan, she will purchase pants, shirts, blouses, skirts, and undergarments, which she will then sell for a small profit.

This is Mariluz’ second loan with Esperanza International. With continued profits, she would like to take her business from the street, as it is now, into her own building. This would save her set-up time and create a more comfortable experience for her customers. Mariluz would also like to purchase a computer for her family to use. A computer is a great expenditure for a low-income household; not only does it give access to the world of information available through the internet, but it also gives children the valuable experience of working with technology, knowledge they will need throughout their lives.

Esperanza International seeks to free children and their families through initiatives that generate income, education and health, restoring self-worth and dignity to those who have lost hope. We have over 8,500 active associates in eleven offices in the Dominican Republic and Haiti. Thank you for lending to Mariluz and the Ruth y Esther group!

loans.use: to purchase pants, blouses, skirts & undergarments for resale

loans.name: Justina

texts.en: Justina O. sells soft drinks and pie (snacks) at Abura near Cape Coast. Justina has received a junior high education. She is married and has two children. Her husband is a driver. Justina has been selling soft drinks and pie for some time now. She supports her husband in the payment of school fees and bills. Her loan will be used to buy more assorted drinks for sale. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to save and to educate her children.

loans.use: Her loan will be used to buy more assorted drinks for sale.

loans.name: Bosangani Plus Group

texts.en:
René A. is the leader of a Community bank named “Bosangani Plus”, which is composed of 26 micro entrepreneurs united in solidarity to receive loans from Kiva through IMF HOPE RDC with the goal of developing their businesses.
René is 56 years old and the father of six children aged 6 to 38. Six of them attend school. René runs a cell phone booth and sells lamp oil. He has been a micro entrepreneur since 2006. He is working hard because his ambition is to become a lamp oil provider in his area. The loan he’ll obtain next will be used to buy 20 liters of lamp oil to resell with the aim of increasing his profits.
As he wants to develop and diversify his business, he decided to join one of Hope’s groups in August 2009. He makes a profit of about $150 per month. René has succeeded with good strategies to build permanent customers. He always talks with his customers, he knows them well by their names, and he never runs out of stock.

loans.use: To purchase 20 liters of lamp oil to resell

location.country: The Democratic Republic of the Congo

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To stock up his store

loans.name: Carmen

texts.es:
La señora Carmen D. tiene el negocio de venta de ropa en el departamento de Masaya ofreciéndolo todos los días a las personas y de esta manera busca la manera de obtener los ingresos para el sustento de su hogar.

El crédito lo ocupará para invertirlo en el negocio y así comprar la ropa para ofrecerla. Es importante que ella  antes de tener el negocio estudiaba y luego empezó el negocio con un pequeño capital y después lo incrementó y así poco a poco ha ido trabajando, ella es soltera y vive con sus padres que les ayuda en lo que necesiten.
texts.en:
Carmen has a business selling clothes. She is requesting a loan to invest into her business and be able to procure more products to offer her customers. Carmen used to study but had to stop to help out her parents with the business. She started the business with few funds, but, with a previous small loan, she has been able to expand the business. Carmen is single and lives with her parents. Carmen runs the business with her parents. Together they want to ensure success for their business.

Translated from Spanish by Justine Raymond, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy trousers for men and women, shirts, paintings, makeup and other products.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To sell food products

loans.name: Francisca Catalina

texts.es: La señora Francisca  tiene el negocio de pulpería el crédito lo solicito para invertirlo en el negocio y a si poder tener mas productos que ofrecerles a sus clientes y de esta manera tener una mayor ganancia, la señora francisca comenzó su negocio con un pequeño capital que poco a poco ha ido incrementando con su esfuerzo ella es madre de cuatro hijos tres ya son independientes y uno esta a su cargo que es por el cual ella se preocupa por darle lo que necesite y esto lo hace con su trabajo levantándose desde muy temprano a tender a sus clientes que la visitan y así darles un buen servicio.
texts.en:
Francisca has a local grocery store. She is requesting a loan to invest into this business and, therefore, be able to expand on her current stock and increase earnings. Francisca started her business of grocery store with a small amount of money, which, little by little has become more successful through her hard work. Francisca is mother to four children, three of whom are independent. Francisca continues to care for one of her children, and, it is for this reason, that she gets up very early in the morning to tend to her customers and provide them with good customer service.

Translated from Spanish by Justine Raymond, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy rice, sugar, cooking oil, beans, dairy products, milk, sweets, and fizzy drinks.

loans.name: Norma

texts.en:
Norma N. is 46 years old, single and lives on the island of Binangonan, an attractive province of Rizal. Reaching older age, she is working hard on her own. She is grateful that there is an ASHI center in her village that offers her inspiration in life and group support to achieve her dreams.


In 2007, she joined ASHI (Ahon SA Hirap Inc.), a microfinance institution and KIVA field partner in the Philippines. Norma cooks and sells fried “itik” (small ducks). She has been in business for more than two years. She believes that her proposed loan of Php 20,000 will contribute to the sustained growth of her business. She will use all of the loan funds to pay for fresh “itik”, as well as inventory for her coco jam business.


Half of her dreams have been gradually achieved, but she is still dreaming about completing them. Norma is a positive and optimistic woman who knows that she will overcome all challenges and achieve her dreams.

loans.use: To pay for fresh " itik" (small duck), as well as inventory for her coco jam business.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To stock up with kerosene for lamps

loans.name: Zoila Rosa

texts.es:
Zoila Rosa S. L. tiene 63 años, es viuda, y vive sola.  Tiene 9 hijos, 5 de los cuales viven en España trabajando en hoteles y 4 están viviendo en Quito.  Uno es policía, otro es gerente de pizza.

La socia pertenece a la ventanilla rural "San Jose de las Orquideas" que está ubicada de 15 minutos de la ciudad de San Miguel en la comunidad de San Jose de Palmas. La gran parte de la comunidad son agricultores y crecen papas y maíz como los principales cultivos.

Zoila se dedica a la agricultura.  Siembra maiz, frejol, habas, lechuga, zuccini, acelga, broculi, y espinaca.  Tiene 5 cuadras de terreno y su casita propia.  Se dedica a esta actividad toda la vida.  Viaja a la ciudad de San Pablo para hacer las ventas de sus productos.

Solicita el préstamo para comprar abonos para invertir en trabajo y sembrar el maiz.  Su sueño para el futuro es que sus hijos estudien para que sean profesionales de algo bonito como ingeniero o artista.  Cuenta que trabajar en el campo es muy duro y la mano de obra y maquinaria son muy caros.
texts.en:
Zoila Rosa S. L. is 63 years old, widowed, and lives by herself. She has nine children, five of whom live in Spain and work at hotels. The other four live in Quito. One is a police officer while another manages a pizzeria.

Zoila is a member of the Communal Bank “San Jose de las Orquideas”, which meets in the community of San Jose de Palmas and is located fifteen minutes away from the city of San Miguel. The majority of the residents of this community are farmers who grow potatoes and corn as their main crops.

Zoila owns her home and has five plots of land in which she grows corn, beans, lima beans, lettuce, zucchini, chard, broccoli, and spinach. She has been farming all of her life and travels to the city of San Pablo to sell her products.

Zoila is requesting a loan to purchase compost for her crop of corn. Her dream for the future is for her children to pursue an education and become a professional such as an engineer or an artist. The work in the fields is very difficult and requires a lot of manual labor. She is not able to acquire machinery because it is too expensive.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase compost for her crops

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To stock up with cereals and retail them

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase a variety of products such as school supplies, beauty products, fabric, and sewing supplies

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase film for the green house, seeds & coal

loans.name: Emilia

texts.es:
LA SEÑORA EMILIA SE DEDICA A LA VENTA DE VACAS AL POR MAYOR Y MENOR. LA SEÑORA LLEVA MAS DE 10 AÑOS EN EL OFICIO, ELLA VIVE EN UN PRECARIA CASA DE BARRO Y PIEDRA, YA QUE LOS ANIMALES QUE TIENE LOS TIENE EN CORRALES ECHOS DE BARRO. LA SEÑORA VIVE CON SU ESPOSO QUE ES ALBAÑIL Y SUS HIJOS, SE LE OTORGO EL CREDITO CON FONDOS KIVA PESE A LOS PROBLEMAS QUE TIENE CON LAS INCLEMENCIAS DEL TIEMPO DE QUE SU CASA POR LAS LLUVIAS SE PUEDA DERRUMBAR. EL DESTINO DEL CREDITO ES PARA AMPLIAR MAS SUS CORRALES DE SUS ANIMALES.EN LA FOTO SE PUEDE VER A SU ESPOSO DE LA SEÑORA YA QUE ELLA ESTABA RECOGIENDO ALFA PARA SUS VACAS.	

LA SRA. EMILIA ESTA MUY AGRADECIDA CON EMPRENDER Y KIVA POR LA CONFIANZA BRINDADA EN LA OTORGACION DEL CREDITO.
texts.en:
Emilia sells cows wholesale and retail. She has been doing this for over ten years. She lives in a meager house made of mud and rocks. She keeps the animals that she has in corrals made of mud. She lives with her husband, a bricklayer, and their children. She got a loan from Kiva because of the problems that she has with inclement weather. Her house could collapse because of the rains. The loan is to enlarge her animal corrals. You can see her husband in the photo because she was gathering alfalfa for her cows. Emilia is very grateful to Emprender and Kiva for the confidence given in granting the loan.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increase work capital

loans.name: Margarita

texts.es:
LA SEÑORA MARGARITA ESTA CASADA Y TIENE 2 HIJOS QUE SE ENCUENTRAN EN EDAD ESCOLAR, SE DEDICA A LA VENTA DE CHANCHOS Y VENTA DE VACAS, LA SEÑORA VIVE EN UNA HUMILDE CASA DE ADOBE (CASA DE BARRO), CRIA CHANCHOS DESDE QUE SON PEQUEÑOS, TAMBIEN CRIA VACAS LECHERAS.  SU TRABAJO ES VASTANTE ARDUO YA QUE SE LEVANTA A LAS CUATRO DE LA MAÑANA PARA DAR COMPRAR ALIMENTOS Y RECOLECTARLOS.LA SEÑORA VIVE CON SU ESPOSO Y SUS HIJOS, ELLOS TAMBIEN LE AYUDAN A SU MAMÁ, A VECES NO VAN A LA ESCUELA SUS HIJOS POR CUIDAR A SUS CHANCHOS Y VACAS DE SU CASA PORQUE HAY MUCHOS LADRONES EN LA ZONA Y MUCHOS VECINOS HAN SUFRIDO ROBOS. EL DESTINO DEL CREDITO ES PARA PODER COMPRAR MAS ALIMENTO PARA EL GANADO Y COMPRAR MAS GANADO. 

LA SRA. MARGARITA ESTA MUY AGRADECIDA AON KIVA Y EMPRENDER POR LA CONFIANZA BRINDADA EN LA OTORGACION DEL CREDITO.
texts.en:
Margarita is married and has two school-age children. She sells pigs and cows. She lives in a meager adobe house (house made of mud). She raises pigs, and she starts when they are little. She also raises dairy cows. Her work is quite arduous. She gets up at four in the morning to feed the animals and to buy and gather the food. She lives with her husband and her children, and they also help their mother. Sometimes her children do not go to school in order to take care of the pigs and cows. There are a lot of robbers in the area, and many neighbors have suffered robberies. The loan is to be able to buy more food for the livestock and to buy more livestock. Margarita is very grateful to Kiva and Emprender for the confidence given in granting the loan.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increase work capital

loans.name: Ruth

texts.es:
LA SEÑORA  RUTH ES CLIENTA DE EMPRENDER, ESTA CASADA Y TIENE HIJOS QUE SE ENCUENTRAN EN EDAD ESCOLAR,ELLA EMPEZO EL TRABAJO DE VENTA DE DULCES EN EL COLEGIO PABLO CANO, ELLA SOLO VENDIA EN LAS AFUERAS DEL COLEGIO EN UN PEQUEÑISIMO CANASTITO DE DULCES, BASTANTE HUMILDE CON LO POCO DE CAPITAL QUE TENIA, AHORA QUE LA SEÑORA YA VENDE MAS DE 10 AÑOS EN LAS AFUERAS DEL COLEGIO, LA DIRECTORA DEL ESTABLECIMIENTO DECIDIO DARLE UN TRABAJO COMO PORTERA DEL COLEGIO YA QUE ELLA MOSTRO UNA GRAN  RESPONSABILIDAD Y DEDICACION AL CUIDADO Y MANTENIMIENTO Y BUEN TRATO A LOS ALUMNOS, ES POR ESA RAZON QUE LA SEÑORA ACCEDIO AL CREDITO CON FONDOS KIVA. SE OBSERVA EN LA FOTO SU KIOSCO CERRADO POR QUE TODAVIA NO EMPEZO LAS CLASES EDUCATIVAS. EL DESTINO DEL CREDITO SERA PARA COMPRAR MAS PRODUCTOS Y PODER LLENAR SU KIOSKO YA QUE YA PRONTO SE INICIARAN LAS CLASES.

LA SRA. RUTH ESTA AGRADECIDA CON EMPRENDER Y KIVA POR LA CONFIANZA BRINDADA EN LA OTORGACION DEL CREDITO.
texts.en:
Ruth is a client of Emprender. She is married and has school-age children. She started the work of selling sweets in the Pablo Cano School. She sold outside the school from a very small basket of sweets. It was quite humble considering the small amount of money that she had. Now she has been selling outside of the school for over ten years. The school principal decided to give her a job as a janitor because Ruth showed great responsibility and dedication to care and maintenance. She also treated the students well. That is why she got a loan with Kiva. In the photo you can see that her kiosk is closed because classes have not started yet. The loan is to buy more products to be able to fill her kiosk because classes will start soon. Ruth is grateful to Emprender and Kiva for the confidence given by granting the loan.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increase work capital

loans.name: Paulina

texts.es:
LA SEÑORA PAULINA ES VIUDA, FUE MUY DURO SUPERAR LA MUERTE D. SU ESPOSO, SE DEDICA A LA VENTA D.  REFRESCOS  DIARIAMENTE SU TRABAJO EMPIEZA A TEMPRANAS HORAS DEL DIA  05:30 D. LA MAÑANA LA SEÑORA SE DESPIERTA PARA HACER HERBIR EL AGUA CON EL CUAL REALIZA SUS DELICIOSOS REFRESCOS D.  CANELA, MANZANA , DURAZNO Y OTROS DEPENDIENDO A LA TEMPORADA. VENDIENDO YA HACE BASTANTE TIEMPO, CUANDO LA INFRAESTRUCTURA DEL MERCADO ERA PRACTICAMENTE TIERRA, ES CONSIDERADA Y RECONOCIDA POR LOS TRASEUNTES. TENIENDO UNA VENTA CONSIDERABLE DURANTE EL DIA ,LA SEÑORA SE RETIRA CONTENTA YA QUE ESTE ES SU UNICO INGRESO PARA MANTENER SU FAMILIA. LA COMPRA D. ESTA HELADERA TENDRA UN VENEFICIO PRODUCTIVO E HIGIÉNICO PARA SU VENTA. 
ESTA MUY AGRADECIDA CON EMPRENDER Y KIVA POR LA CONFIANZA BRINDADA EN LA OTORGACION DEL CREDITO
texts.en:
Paulina is a widow. It was very hard to get over the death of her husband. She sells cold drinks everyday. Her work starts early in the day at 5:30 in the morning. She gets up in order to start boiling the water she uses to make her delicious drinks. The drinks are cinnamon, apple, peach and other kinds, depending on the season. She has been selling for quite a while, since the market’s infrastructure was almost all dirt. She is respected and known to the passers-by. Having considerable sales during the day, she ends her day happily because this is her only source of income to support her family. The purchase of this refrigerator will have a productive and hygienic benefit on her sales. She is grateful to Emprender and Kiva for the confidence given by granting the loan.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy a refrigerator

loans.name: Lucita

texts.en:
Lucita A. is a 47-year-old woman with the strong courage to get out from the ties of poverty. She is a mother to six children; four of them are of legal age and the other one is a minor.  She is married to Simeon A., a vendor.  Unfortunately, the salary of her husband is insufficient for their daily needs.


As a woman of big dreams, in 2008 she joined ASHI (Ahon Sa Hirap, Inc.), a Microfinance Institution and KIVA partner in the Philippines. Since receiving the loan, she started a primary business of selling dry goods, which has helped support the financial needs of the family.  Now on her fourth loan, she is requesting 20,000 PHP to continue her primary business (dry goods) and pay for inventory (including dresses, shorts, underwear, sando, t-shirts, polo shirts and blouses) for her secondary business.


She hopes that, with the moral and financial support of ASHI and KIVA, she can reach her ambition to expand both businesses, pay for the needs of her children's education, and step out of the cycle of poverty.

loans.use: To continue her primary business (dry goods) and pay for inventory for her secondary business of RTW (ready-to-wear-clothes).

loans.name: Jose Leonel

texts.es:
Perfil del Cliente 	El Sr. José Leonel Solís tiene una taller de soldadura en el municipio del el Viejo, el va a usar este crédito en la compra de 2 pistolas de soldar que necesita, una caja de herramientas, y varillas para soldar ya que en la actualidad han salido varios tipos de llaves que le sirven para hacer mas fácil su trabajo.

El Sr. Solís ya tiene varios años con este taller, el cual a través de las ganancias que ha obtenido ahora tiene una panadería en su casa la cual  administra su esposa, además de tener dos camionetas y un microbús que son su medio de transporte para salir a vender el pan. 

Este es el cuarto crédito que ha tenido con CEPRODEL,  el cual nos manifiesta que le han sido de gran ayuda para mejorar su trabajo y su vida personal, ya que gracias a ellos su negocio ha crecido y le ha dejado mayores ganancias.
texts.en:
José Leonel Solís has a soldering shop in the Viejo municipality. He will use this loan to buy two soldering irons that he needs, a toolbox, and soldering rods. There are now various types of wrenches that make his work easier. Mr. Solís has had this shop for several years. With the income he has obtained he now has a bakery, which he wife runs, in his house. He also has two vans and a minibus, which he uses when he leaves to sell the bread. This is his fourth loan with Ceprodel. He says that they have been a great help in improving his work and his personal life. Thanks to the loans his business has grown and given him greater earnings.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy two soldering irons, a tool box with all types of wrenches and sockets, and soldering rods, etc.

loans.name: Dorcas

texts.fr: I. Dorcas est née en 1980 et vit au quartier Sodjatimey à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin, depuis 10 ans.  Dorcas est mariée à SOKENOU Ludovic, un frigoriste, et mère de trois enfant, tous scolarisés. Dorcas vit ensemble avec ses enfants et son mari et le couple supporte ensemble les charges de la famille.  Dorcas n’a jamais été à l’école.  Pour contribuer à supporter les charges familiales, Dorcas vend les divers (oeufs, huile de palme, farine de manioc) et les condiments de sauce (tomate, oignons, piments) à son domicile. Dorcas s’approvisionne à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin.  Dorcas exerce cette activité depuis 7 ans.  Dorcas est une ancienne cliente de ALIDé, ayant déjà obtenu cinq crédits à ALIDé, crédits qu’elle a bien remboursés.  Dorcas sollicite un sixième crédit auprès à ALIDé en vue de renforcer ses activités et de mieux répondre à la forte demande de sa clientèle.
texts.en:
I. Dorcas was born in 1980 and has been living in the Sodjatimey district in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin, for ten years.  She is married to SOKENOU Ludovic, a refrigeration specialist, and is the mother of three children, who are all in school.  She lives together with her children and husband, and the couple jointly support the family.   Dorcas never attended school.  To take part in meeting family expenses, she sells a variety of goods (eggs, palm oil, cassava flour) and sauce condiments (tomatoes, onions, chili peppers) out of her home.  She gets her supplies at Dantokpa, the international market of Benin.  She has been in this business for seven years. She is a previous client of ALIDé having already obtained five loans from ALIDé, and she has repaid them.  Dorcas is requesting a sixth loan from Dorcas for bolstering her business and responding better to the strong customer demand.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Bolstering her business and buying various goods and condiments for making sauce

loans.name: Maria

texts.es: María, es una mujer muy trabajadora, vive en el Distrito D. Calleria, región Ucayali, tiene 55 años, es madre D. cuatro hijos que ya son independientes, ella se dedica a administrar su bar, esta actividad la realiza en su casa, actualmente no cuenta con el apoyo D.  esposo porque se encuentra enfermo. María forma parte del Banco Comunal “Mujeres solidarias”, desD. hace un año y medio, el primer crédito que recibió fue D. 300 soles, que fue invertido en la compra D. productos para su negocio, ahora ella necesita un crédito D. 400 soles, que será invertido en la compra D. golosinas y otros productos para su negocio. La meta D. María es seguir trabajando para poner una bodega y ampliar su negocio.
texts.en:
María is a hardworking woman who lives in the District of Calleria, Ucayali Region. She manages a bar located in her home. At the moment, her husband does not proviD. financial support because of illness.

María has been a member of the Communal Bank “Mujeres Solidarias” (United Women) for 1½ years. The first loan she received was in the amount of 300 soles and used to buy products for her business. She is now requesting a loan of 400 soles to invest in candy and other products to sell at her business. María’s goal is to continue working by opening a grocery store and expanding her existing business.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase candy & other products to sell at her business

loans.name: Mujeres Unidas Con Propositos 1 & 2 Group

texts.en:
Eladia, 49, is a borrower who lives in Santiago, Dominican Republic. She is the coordinator for her group, Mujeres Unidas con Propositos (United Women with Purpose), and her story is representative of those in her group and other Dominican and Haitian borrowers at Esperanza International.

Eladia and her husband live in a simple home in Santiago with their two children. Santiago is the second-largest city in the Dominican Republic. Life in urban areas of the Dominican Republic is overcrowded and can be rough, with no potable running water, frequent power outages (if one has power to begin with), and inadequate healthcare. Despite these difficulties, Eladia runs a successful business selling miscellaneous items to her friends and neighbors. With this loan, she will purchase perfumes, clothing, appliances, and sweets to sell for a small profit at her street stand.

This is Eladia’s fifth loan with Esperanza International. With continued profits, Eladia hopes to purchase a small truck so that she can buy her merchandise more easily and in greater quantities. She also hopes to support her children’s education with the benefits from her business, making sure that they receive the best schooling possible. In the future, Eladia hopes to purchase her own store and continue increasing the size of her sales and customer base.

Esperanza International seeks to free children and their families through initiatives that generate income, education and health, restoring self-worth and dignity to those who have lost hope. We have over 8,500 active associates in eleven offices in the Dominican Republic and Haiti. Thank you for lending to Eladia and the Mujeres Unidas con Propositos group!

loans.use: To purchase clothing, perfume, appliances, and sweets for resale

loans.name: Manuel Napoleon

texts.es:
Manuel Napoleon L. M. tiene 52 años de edad y su estado civil es union libre.  Tiene 3 hijos de 7, 6, y 5 años.

El socio pertenece a la ventanilla rural "San Jose de las Orquideas" que está ubicada de 15 minutos de la ciudad de San Miguel en la comunidad de San Jose de Palmas. La gran parte de la comunidad son agricultores y crecen papas y maíz como los principales cultivos.

Manuel se dedica a la agricultura y siembra maiz, papa, coles, y zanahoria. Hace todas sus compras y ventas de sus productos en San Pablo y en San Miguel.  Lo dificil de trabajar en el campo es que a veces por el clima no se puede cosechar y se sufre sin ganar dinero que se invierte en la agricultura.

Solicita el crédito para trabajar en la agricultura en la compra de abonos, semillas, urea, etc.  Le gusta a Manuel más el campo que la ciudad porque se puede ser más libre.  Su esperanza es que sean profesionales sus hijos y eligan unas carreras buenas como instructor.
texts.en:
Manuel Napoleon L. M. is 52 years old and in a common law marriage. He has three children, ages 7, 6, and 5.

He is a member of the Communal Bank “San Jose de las Orquideas”, which meets in the community of San Jose de Palmas and is located fifteen minutes away from the city of San Miguel. The majority of the residents of this community are farmers who grow potatoes and corn as their main crops.

Manuel is a farmer himself and grows corn, potatoes, cabbage, and carrots. He buys and sells his products in San Pablo and San Miguel. The most difficult part of his job is not being able to harvest crops because of the weather. As a result, he is not able to earn money and recoup the investment from his crops.

Manuel is requesting a loan to purchase farming supplies such as compost, seeds, urea, and other items. He enjoys living on a farm instead of in the city because there is more freedom. Manuel hopes that his children will become professionals and pursue a good career such as teaching.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase compost, seeds, urea, etc.

loans.name: Pascaline

texts.fr: V. Pascaline est née vers 1960 à Abomey, une ville historique du Bénin, mais elle vit au quartier Fidjrossè à Cotonou, capital économique du Bénin, depuis 10 ans.  Pascaline est mariée à GBEKAN Martial,un cuisinier. Le couple a quatre enfants, tous scolarisés, dont trois sont à leur charge. Pascaline vit ensemble avec son mari et ses enfants et le couple supporte ensemble les charges de la famille.  Pascaline n’a jamais été à l’école.  Pour supporter les charges familiales, Pascaline vend des tenues et divers produits dans sa boutique et de façon ambulante.  Pascaline exerce cette activité depuis 20 ans et s’approvisionne à Lomé, au Togo (pays a coté de Bénin). Pascaline a déjà obtenu des crédits à ALIDé – ces crédits ont été bien remboursés.  Elle sollicite un autre crédit auprès de ALIDé pour renforcer son activité et acheter plus des tenues et divers.
texts.en:
V. Pascaline was born 1960 Abomey, a historic city of Benin.  But she has been living in the Fidjrossè district in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin, for ten years.  She is married to GBEKAN Martial, a cook.  The couple have four children, all in school, and three of them are in their care. Pascaline lives together with her husband and children, and the couple jointly support the family.   Pascaline never attended school.  To cover family expenses, she sells outfits and a variety of goods in her shop and by going door-to-door.  She has been in this business for twenty years and gets her supplies in Lomé, Togo (a country bordering Benin).   She has already obtained loans from ALIDé -- these loans have been repaid. She is requesting another loan from ALIDé for bolstering her business and buying more outfits and other goods.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying outfits

loans.name: Miriam

texts.es:
Según su asesora de crédito, Miriam C. Q. es una mujer que “no se queda quieta”; ella es una comerciante, muy emprendedora y residente del barrio La Playa de Barranquilla, tiene 63 años y tres hijos entre las edades de 42 y 23 años. Su negocio consiste en la venta de varios tipos de mercancía que comercializa según la época del año. Con el crédito de $1.500.000 que ahora solicita quiere comprar  telas y accesorios –como escudos bordados- para uniformes de un colegio cercano.
Con el lema “de todo un poquito”, el negocio de Miriam abarca muchas cosas: Hace diez años vendía zapatos de colegio y hace siete adicionó helados y mercancías por catálogos. Ahora su negocio incluye la venta y elaboración de chichas -un tipo de bebida hecha de maíz o arroz- y de bolis -un helado típico de Colombia- y elaboración de artesanía en hilo tejidas,  o pintadas en tela y/o  con escarcha. También se dedica a vender mercancías  por catálogo o por encargo: calzados, accesorios para damas como aretes y bisutería y listas de libros. 
Se enteró de la Fundación por vecinos y recomendaciones hace cinco años y desde entonces ha tenido siete créditos. Cuida mucho su crédito y trata de participar en todos los programas de la Fundación, tanto en el programa de legalización con la Cámara de Comercio, como en actividades lúdicas, por ejemplo el bingo o paseos. Además, toma cursos para actualizar sus conocimientos para vender siempre lo que esté de moda. Considera que su vinculación a la Fundación ha sido positiva, puesto que se mantiene activa y útil y que ha podido obtener mucho de lo que necesita. Ahora sueña con terminar la casa donde vive con toda su familia.
texts.en:
According to her loan officer, Miriam C. Q. is a woman who “cannot keep still”. She is an enterprising businesswoman who lives in the neighborhood of La Playa in Barranquilla. She is 63 years old and has three children between the ages of 23 and 42. Miriam manages a business selling different types of merchandise based on the time of year. With the loan of 1,500,000 COP that she is requesting, she will buy fabrics and accessories (such as borders) for making uniforms for the local high school.

“Everything for less” is the slogan for Miriam’s business where she sells many things. For ten years, she sold school shoes and for seven years, she sold ice cream and catalog merchandise. Her business now includes the production and sale of “chicha”, a beverage made from corn or rice, and “bolis” (a traditional form of ice cream found in Colombia). She also makes handicrafts made of woven threads, painted fabrics, or frosted glass. In addition she sells merchandise through catalog or by request such as shoes, women’s accessories (earrings, costume jewelry, etc.), and reading material.

Miriam learned about the Foundation five years ago from neighbors and through other recommendations. Since then she has taken out seven loans. Miriam is very careful with her loans and tries to take advantage of all of the services offered by the Foundation, such as the licensing program provided through the Chamber of Commerce. She also enjoys fun activities, such as playing bingo or taking walks. The courses she has taken have updated her knowledge in selling products that are always in fashion. Miriam believes her working relationship with the Foundation has been a positive experience, so she remains active and tries to obtain as much as she can as long as the benefits are useful. She now dreams of finishing the home in which she lives with her family.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase fabrics & accessories for making school uniforms

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Buying a motorbike taxi

loans.name: Alodia

texts.es: Alodia, es una mujer muy puntual, vive en el Distrito de Manantay, región Ucayali, tiene  38 años, es madre de cinco hijos, dos son dependientes, ella se dedica a la venta de repuestos de motores, esta actividad la realiza en su puesto que tiene en el puerto, cuenta con el apoyo de su pareja que se desempeña como mecánico. Alodia forma parte del Banco Comunal “El Fruto Bendito”, desde hace 2 años, el primer crédito que recibió fue de 300 soles, que fue invertido en la venta de comida, ahora ella necesita un crédito de 1000 soles, que será invertido en la compra de repuestos y colas de motores fuera de borda. La meta de Alodia es seguir trabajando para ampliar su negocio de compra y venta de motores.
texts.en:
Alodia is a very punctual woman who lives in the District of Manantay, Ucayali Region. She is 38 years old and the mother of five children, two of whom are dependents.
